speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise with reference to notice of a matter of privilege which I filed with the Chair late yesterday afternoon.
A sequence of events took place in the House yesterday at approximately 5 p.m. that I feel is a breach-I hope the Chair will feel that way-of the clear intentions of the members of the House. It may have involved a misunderstanding on the part of the Chair. I hope the Speaker will accept that I want to put the matter in a way that does not indicate disrespect for the Chair.
It is an attempt to put right what I believe is a matter that has not been done right. It involves a matter of procedure.
In order to do that, Mr. Speaker, I have to very briefly indicate the sequence to you so you can understand the perspective of the members. I do not think I speak only on behalf of myself. There are other members who have a very clear interest in this.
In essence, the Chair yesterday terminated debate on a question before the House. In fact, there were two questions. There was a second reading motion and an amendment to the second reading motion.
The Speaker at 5 p.m., give or take one minute on either side of 5 p.m., terminated debate in the following sequence. It happened in the clear face of information which I believe the Chair had within his knowledge.
There was an agreement among the House leaders that the matter before the House at that time would have at least two day's debate. On Wednesday, it was clearly stated that this coming Monday the matter of Bill
C-63 would continue to be debated. That is clear in the record.
Second, the Chair had a list of speakers in his possession which clearly showed a continuing sequence of members wishing to speak to the matter then before the House.
Third, the Speaker had the benefit of two discussions with the member for Ottawa-Vanier which indicated to the Speaker at approximately 4.35 p.m. that he wished to speak to the matter, everyone with their eye on the clock. The Chair indicated, as I think the member for Ottawa-Vanier will indicate later, that the Speaker would want to recognize a member from the New Democratic Party and the Speaker did that.
The record shows that the Speaker recognized the member for Windsor-St. Clair at a point in time following 1640. Hansard shows the member for Park-dale-High Park speaking at 1640. That is on page 9942 of Hansard.
At a point in time following 1640, the Speaker recognized the member for Windsor-St. Clair. That member had, based on the rules of the House, 20 minutes to complete his remarks. If the full 20 minutes had been used, that would have taken him up to 5 p.m.
As the sequence evolved, the Speaker interrupted the member for Windsor-St. Clair. It was assumed by all members in the House, as I understand it, to be 5 p.m. That was when the Speaker rose and said to the member speaking at that time: "I regret the hon. member's time has expired".
Based on Hansard, that could only mean that we had arrived at 5 p.m. If he had commenced to speak following 1640 and if the Chair felt that time had expired, it could only have been 5 p.m.
The rules of the House call for the House to interrupt business at that time and proceed to Private Members' Business. That is what members believed would happen. That is what members on this side of the House believed would have happened, including the member for Ottawa-Vanier who had gone back to the Speaker in the Chair to verify that he would not have an opportunity to speak if the member for Windsor-St. Clair used all of

May 1, 1992
Privilege
his time. On that basis several members in this House had gone into their respective lobbies.
At 5 p.m., having interrupted the member for Windsor-St. Clair, the Chair immediately put the question. He said: "Is the House ready for the question?" He said nothing else. This surprised a number of members in the lobbies, as I understand it.
The Chair then asked if it was the pleasure of the House to adopt the amendment. Members, still surprised, it being assumed we were dealing with a five o'clock interruption gave several answers which are not clear from Hansard.
The member for Carleton-Gloucester on this side of the House then rose in his place and asked the Chair if there was not a five-minute period of questions and comments now due. That is what usually occurs.
The Chair then said to that member: "I asked for questions or comments. Nobody was getting up. Is it the pleasure of the House to adopt the amendment?"
That, Mr. Speaker, was an incorrect statement by the Chair. I am sure it was inadvertent because the record shows clearly that the Chair did not ask for questions and comments.
I submit to you that any Speaker in the Chair would have been aware of all of which I have already said; the agreement of the House leaders, the speakers' list, the discussion with the member for Ottawa-Vanier, the point of order raised by the member for Carleton- Gloucester, and would have recognized the desire of all members to continue with the debate. In fact House business for Monday is set for the continuation of debate.
In the face of that the Chair proceeded-it must have been five o'clock, Mr. Speaker-to deal with the question and call for a vote which no member was prepared for and in fact it required an impromptu intervention in an effort to delay and defer the vote until next week.
I suggest to you, Mr. Speaker, that-

I have of course watched the videotape very carefully. The hon. member just said that it required
an impromptu intervention after five o'clock. Perhaps the hon. member could explain that a bit more thoroughly-

Perhaps, Mr. Speaker, I should not have used the word impromptu. It was certainly an event which had not been foreseen by anyone and I might refer it to as ad hoc. The rules of the House provide for the deferral of a vote, but this was a vote that had matured because in my view of the determination of the Chair.

I have listened very, very carefully. I cannot speak for some of the events that the hon. member has put forward which would be conversations between the speaker and the Chair, but I have watched the tape very closely and I just wanted to be absolutely certain on this. The hon. member is instructing me and is putting forward as the facts that the vote was called, the members were called in, and as I understand it, the Whip then asked for a deferment of the vote.
Is that the event to which the hon. member is referring, the impromptu intervention? I was not aware of any further intervention as a point of order.
Mr. Speaker, it was not a point of order. It was simply what is sometimes a routine request by the government to defer the taking of a vote.

I understand now and I thank you for it.
I wonder if I could hear the hon. government House leader. Then I shall return to other members.

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member from Scarborough who has raised this question of privilege is right in the sense that we did anticipate the debate on second reading of this bill would go on to Monday, and indeed from the government's perspective we were operating on that basis.
I was as surprised as anybody else when the votes were taken at five o'clock. I have examined the tapes and have watched what happened. I looked at Hansard and it seems pretty clear what happened. The opposition was asleep at the switch.
May 1, 1992

The Speaker heard the member for Windsor-St. Clair speak. There was no protest from the member for Windsor-St. Clair about being cut off so he assumed the time was done. He then asked whether the House was ready for the question. I listened. There is nothing in Hansard about any protest from any members. There are no points of order. Things proceeded in a routine fashion and when the second reading debate was held there were five members.
It appears that a lot of people like yours truly were watching the Ontario budget on television. That notwithstanding, we have a decision of the House which says there will be a deferred vote on this bill on Monday.
There was no ambush here. There was no collusion. There was nothing untoward. As I say, basically from my perspective the opposition was asleep at the switch.
However, what I would like to propose is that we agree to a House order that might say the following:
That, notwithstanding any order of this House, on Monday, May 4, 1992 the House allow further debate on the motion for second reading of Bill C-63, an act to dissolve or terminate certain corporations and other bodies, provided that no further amendments be allowed and that deferred division to dispose of second reading of said bill be taken no later than 6 p.m. that day.
I think I heard hon. members say that they anticipated, the Liberal Party anyway, two days of debate. I believe the New Democratic Party House leader would agree that there was agreement for two days of debate. I think this provides the extra opportunity for the debate to occur and I think this is the proper resolution to this issue.
Otherwise we end up with a long and involved discussion about who said what to whom, when in fact if we look at the record in Hansard and at a replay of what occurred on television it was very clear that there were no points of order. There was no protest at the time to anything that occurred and what happened was a natural, normal thing with people not being here.
I think this is the resolution and I would commend it to the House for its consideration.

I will hear the hon. member for Cape Breton-East Richmond. Then I will come to the hon. member for Windsor-St. Clair again, if that is necessary.
Privilege

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I wish to make seven points.
The first point: I have reviewed Hansard, which I am sure the Chair has done and the Table has done. I am certain the Chair has taken the time to review the electronic recording of our proceedings. I am sure it will note that the hon. member for Windsor-St. Clair started his debate after 4.40 p.m. yesterday. The tapes will show that the member was still speaking when the Chair interrupted. There is no way then that the House was still on government time, and therefore the question in my view should not have been put.
The second point: The Chair in putting the motion failed to ask for questions and comments. I know the Chair is paying attention, but I just want to emphasize that the Chair did not follow the proceedings, which was to ask for questions and comments.
The third point: The hon. member for Carleton- Gloucester stood in his place on a point of order and asked the Chair specifically if there was not a time for questions and answers, to which the Chair replied, and I say so with great respect, perhaps innocently that he had asked for questions and comments when in fact Hansard and the tape will show he did not ask. Others have used stronger language. I would prefer to use an innocent mistake.
The fourth point: If is was not after 5 p.m. when the Chair put the question on the amendment, it certainly was after the amendment was disposed of and he should never have proceeded with the main motion.
The fifth point: The Chair failed to ask for further debate on the main motion as indicated in Hansard and as indicated by the tape.
The sixth point: My distinguished colleague from Ottawa-Vanier will testily, if given an opportunity in these proceedings, that the Chair knew that he wished to speak after the hon. member for Windsor-St. Clair. In fact the Chair and the hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier agreed that since the hon. member for Windsor-St. Clair said he was taking his full 20 minutes, my colleague for Ottawa-Vanier would not be able to get on before Monday. The Chair had agreed to that in discussion that they had at the table. My colleague will verify that.

May 1, 1992
Privilege
The seventh point I make is one of fairness. The rules of natural justice would suggest that one who occupies the chair for members and who is to serve members would want to be fair. I suggest that it would be terribly unfair if we were to proceed as if everything was fine in the suggestion made by the government House leader. I do not think that would be fair.
I would respectfully request that the Chair give serious consideration as to the consequences of this kind of debate and discussion on a measure which is important for the opposition as well as for all members.

Mr. Speaker, it would seem to me that the facts of yesterday are not in dispute. I would simply say it is not unusual for this member to be relatively unconscious of the length of time that he has spoken. As a matter of fact, on occasion when I have lost track of time and expressed my regret for that, someone has said I could have always looked at the calendar.
I have to enter into the debate my own observations of yesterday. I can tell you with confidence that I began to speak shortly after 4.45 p.m. At about 4.58 p.m., the Speaker exhibited a number of distracting gestures of impatience that led me to believe that in spite of the evidence of my senses I had spoken for longer than I had.
It is clear therefore I was interrupted before the completion of the time that would normally be allocated to me. The record clearly indicates that the Acting Speaker did not ask for questions or comments, that he did not call for debate, that there was objection raised but that was dismissed rather quickly and the Acting Speaker continued to put the question on the amendment and on the main motion.
I am glad to hear the hon. House leader on the government side propose a possible solution to this series of unfortunate events. I think it regrettable therefore in this context that we hear such phraseology as the opposition was asleep at the switch. Given the events and the manner in which they unfolded, there being at the time as I recall about three members in the House, it is clear that there really was no opportunity short of engaging in an unnecessary and perhaps provocative exchange with the Acting Speaker to deal with the issue as it was presented to us. We were all shocked and surprised and therefore in some degree paralysed.
However inadvertent the series of events might have been and the acceptance on our part that this was not deliberate as suggested by the House leader, because that is not our suggestion, nevertheless I think we should be conscious of the fact there has been concern from time to time that these kinds of inadvertencies have occurred with too much frequency in this House when you, Sir, are not in the chair.
I think all of us would be very much more satisfied if not only this incident is dealt with appropriately, perhaps as suggested by the leader of the government side, but that care be exercised ensuring that this kind of unnecessary intervention in the process of debate be avoided by exercising greater care on the part of who may be acting in the chair in the future.
I want to thank the hon. member for Windsor-St. Clair and especially the tone with which he has proceeded.

Mr. Speaker, since the description given of yesterday's incident and the facts involved seems quite accurate, I will not repeat what was said by the Liberal House leader and the hon. member for Windsor-St. Clair.
I myself was involved because Bill C-63 before the House is a bill that we on this side of the House feel is extremely important. I had indicated to the House around 4.30 p.m. that I wanted to speak in the debate on Bill C-63. The Speaker-and I repeat this because I want to put my experience of the facts on the record- who was in the Chair at the time, and I am referring to the Deputy Chairman of Committees of the Whole, told me that he had to recognize a member for the New Democratic Party. I agreed, because in the House it is the custom to alternate between government and opposition speakers.
I asked him at the time whether he knew if any NDP members wanted to speak. He answered: "No, I don't have any names; would you check?" I went to check, and I saw my colleague from Windsor-St. Clair. I asked him specifically whether he intended to take the floor. He said yes. I asked him whether he was going to take the full 20 minutes to which he was entitled, and he said yes.
May 1, 1992

At this point it was about 4.40 p.m. You can check the records of the clerks at the Thble. The records indicate . that it was 4.40 p.m. I had another committee meeting, so I went to this meeting because I figured: 4.40 p.m., a 20-minute speech, since the hon. member had given me the assurance he would speak for 20 minutes, and a 10-minute period for questions and comments-impossible, I would come back Monday. I went to see the Speaker and told him exactly this: Mr. Speaker, I will not be able to speak today, so I will see you Monday. He said: Have a nice weekend, Jean-Robert. Then I left and went to my committee meeting. The bells started ringing at 5.01 or 5.02, at which point we wondered what was happening.
Quite frankly, I consider that my privileges have been breached because the Chair knew that I wanted to speak and that it was impossible for me to do so yesterday, because according to the clocks there was no time left. In fact, I would also like to say something about the clocks. Look at the time. One clock says 10.29, the other clock says 10.30 and the third, 10.31. The Speaker's clock is the one that counts, I agree. But the hon. member for Windsor-St. Clair was interrupted in the middle of his speech by the Chair and told his time had expired. That is impossible. According to the official record on the Thble, he started at 4.40 p.m. Now, the Speaker's clock may not show the same time as the clock used by the clerks, but the fact remains that the hon. member had 19 minutes, not 20. When the hon. member for Carleton- Gloucester rose to ask him whether there was not a period of questions and comments after a speech on second reading, the Speaker answered: I asked for questions and comments. Nobody was getting up.
We are dealing with members who take the Chair seriously. When the Speaker rises, members must take their seat. When the Speaker makes a statement, members do not usually question that statement. The hon. member for Carleton-Gloucester, out of respect for the Speaker, took this decision, this statement, this affirmation as a fact, as a decision by the Chair. In the Parliament of Canada, we do not question the decisions of the Chair, as you well know, Mr. Speaker. We cannot challenge them. When the government House leader
Privilege
says there was no collusion and there was nothing irregular, this is inaccurate because we never said there was collusion. We only said it was an error of judgment, a factual error, an error in time, and that in our view, a decision was made by the Chair that was misleading for the Liberal members. The hon. member for Carleton- Gloucester, out of respect for the Chair, chose to abide by that decision, which was unfortunate for us, because we lost our right to speak.
I may recall what it says in Beauchesne's, Fifth Edition:
117. The chief characteristics attached to the office of the Speaker in the House are authority and impartiality. [ -JReflections upon the character or actions of the Speaker may be punished as breaches of privilege. His actions cannot be criticized incidentally in debate or upon any form of proceeding except by way of a substantive motion.
As I said earlier, when the Speaker says something, we do not question what he says.
When our right to speak is restricted, when a restriction has been put on my right to speak, I say that some remedy is needed. I say there is something we must straighten out. Perhaps the Speaker's clock was not running properly yesterday or perhaps it was an oversight, but I think we have serious reasons to believe that this is a question of privilege. If this matter is not dealt with, I feel I will have to do whatever can be done to ensure that something is done about this situation.
I thank the hon. member for Ottawa- Vanier. I think that the hon. member for Edmonton Southwest is ready to speak.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will be very brief because I intervene only in my new capacity as parliamentary secretary to the government House leader. I was not present when this event occurred. However, I have reviewed Hansard and I have seen the television portrayal of what occurred.
I believe that there is genuine dispute as to whether the question was properly put. There is some difficulty because the Hansard and the tape cannot record agreements or undertakings that were given. We rely on each other's word in that regard and I do not believe anyone

May 1, 1992
Privilege
has suggested that any word has been broken in this instance. Nor is there a record of lists that may have been kept or of conversations with the Chair, nor is any switch at which one may or may not have been asleep in evidence. Therefore, it is unfortunate that we cannot deal with those facts.
It is clear that at least from the tape there did not appear to be anyone standing to participate in debate when the vote was called. However, I wish to reiterate that the issue before us is an issue of fairness. I agree with other speakers who have made that point. I believe that what is proposed by the government House leader is the appropriate course to follow; that the undertaking given to the other House leaders to continue the debate on Monday be followed through with and that the deferred vote be taken no later than 6 p.m. on Monday.
I am in the hands of the Chair as to whether it would be appropriate to pose such a motion. I would rather hear from the Chair before considering that action.

Mr. Speaker, I had not really had an opportunity to complete my remarks when we moved on to other members. I want to point out that when I rose on this matter following Prayers at ten o'clock, in terms of Parliamentary time this incident was no older than about three to five minutes.
If one looks at Hansard, it is very clear that when the Chair called for the question, the member for Carle-ton-Gloucester rose on what he called a point of order. He was really rising to ask a question. The Chair inadverently, not realizing that he had failed to ask for questions or comments as he believed he had, did not pay attention to actually what was a request to make questions or comments. That happened within about 20 seconds. I want to focus on that timeframe. I believe that in fairness the Chair should be looking at that and recognizing that the Chair may have acted in a misinformed manner without indicating where the misinformation came from. Perhaps, even if we are talking about switches, it involved the Speaker's own clock, which he sometimes relies on in timing debates.

Mr. Speaker, the events of yesterday afternoon were unfortunate
but they have happened and we are now in a position of that being recorded.
There has been a good deal of talk today about the evidence and what the evidence proves. As I listened, it occurred to me that the tape does not prove that the Chair did not ask for questions and comments, but neither is there any evidence that it did ask. There is some question about that.
Nevertheless, we are in the position in which quite a number of members wanted to carry on the debate and the government has offered a way of achieving what we all want to do. We do not want to be talking about this, we want to be talking about the issues. We want to be talking about the bill.
I have some argument about the agreement about two days. Certainly our executive was not informed that we had agreed in a House leaders meeting to a two-day debate. Neither have we disagreed. It was not decided. I understand it is not totally unusual for three House leaders to come out of that meeting with slightly different ideas as to exactly what was agreed upon in those meetings.
However, it would seem to me that taking the government House leader's suggestion and discussing the motion he proposes to move some time perhaps during Question Period or between now and Question Period among the House leaders, and coming up with a motion upon which we could all agree to cany on the debate on Monday, might be the best way of getting out of this at this time.

Hon. members, starting with the hon. member for Scarborough-Rouge River, have been extremely co-operative and helpful to the Chair.
First of all, I want to comment on this because I do not want any misunderstanding. I have listened very carefully to our colleague, the hon. member for Ottawa-Vani-er, and I want him to know this.

I very well understand the concern of the hon. member for Ottawa-Vanier with respect to the events of yesterday afternoon.
May 1, 1992



I say that because I do not want anybody to think that the situation that happened yesterday is something that the Chair takes lightly.
I also want to comment on something else. I hope that sometimes those who are so critical of this place will note what I am saying. There has been an attempt made today, an honourable one and a helpful one, to take the position that what happened may well have been inadvertence. Under the circumstances that is helpful.
The hon. member for Nanaimo-Cowichan has suggested that perhaps this matter could be delayed for a little while for further discussion with respect to whether the matter can be resolved by the suggestion of the hon. government House leader, which is to carry on the debate on Monday and to have the vote on Monday night without any further amendments.
The hon. member for Edmonton Southwest was clearly supporting the suggesting made by his own government House leader, but he did ask the Chair if its comments might help to guide the House. That is what the hon. member was reaching for. Perhaps my comments can help. At the moment I do not have to make this ruling, but I want to indicate to hon. members that it would be with some difficulty that the Chair, given what happened yesterday, could overrule a decision of the House. It would be a very difficult position to be in.
We have a suggestion now that while it does not extinguish the events of yesterday, it certainly goes a long way to meet the serious concerns that have been expressed. The hon. member Windsor-St. Clair was very helpful with the comments that he made.
I am going to put to the House the proposition of the government House leader, which the House has heard; namely, that the House Order about the debate on this bill recommence on Monday, that it proceed during the day, that there would be no further amendments and that the vote on the main motion would take place at six p.m. That is the proposition which is, in my view, presently before the House and I would like to hear comment on that.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am disappointed but one has to come to understand certain realities with regard to this institution. Members on this side of the House have indicated to the Chair the fact that there probably was some inadvertence; an honest mistake. I am seeking guidance from the Chair. The Chair has indicated that a
Privilege
decision has been made properly in this House. Not notwithstanding that, the Chair is not inclined to overrule that decision.
Now the Chair wishes to put before the House a government suggestion on a motion that we terminate the debate at six o'clock on Monday.
That is what the Chair has now suggested to us; to continue with the debate on Monday and terminate the debate on second reading of the main motion at six o'clock.

I hesitate very much to interrupt the hon. leader, but I am only putting to the House the suggestion of the government House leader. It is not my suggestion. If that is not acceptable, there may have to be further discussions.
I hope it is not misunderstood. I am not ordering that. I am saying that there is a suggestion on the floor of the House and I am seeking the advice of the House on whether it should be accepted.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Perhaps the Chair could indicate to the House, since the Chair services the members in this House, as to whether the suggestion which is being put forward by my colleagues opposite is fair and appropriate in view of what the Chair has viewed in Hansard, from what it has heard on the tape and from the interventions which have been made by members of this House.
Does the Chair believe that to be an appropriate remedy in view of those facts?

The hon. member may be putting the Chair in some difficulty.
I am trying to respond to the hon. member for Edmonton Southwest. I am trying to assist the House. I have not ruled this. I am suggesting that under the circumstances it would be very difficult for a Speaker to rule that what happened yesterday was not a decision of the House.
If that is the dilemma that the Speaker would be in, if the Speaker had to proceed to make that ruling, and I am doing this only to be helpful, then one seeks another resolution of this so that this can be dealt with as fairly as possible.
I am cognizant of the fact that I have been instructed today that there was at least an arrangement, an understanding, between the members of the Official Opposition and the government that it would be a two-day debate.

May 1, 1992
Privilege
A minimum of having two days.
Have I misunderstood that?

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext: Yes, you have.
I am very sorry. I will hear the hon. member for Cape Breton-East Richmond.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
I would like to clarify that.
The hon. member, when he made reference to two days, was under the impression that it was to be for at least two days because of the comments which were made by the government House leader and the fact that the bill was going to be called for Monday's debate.
There was no agreement by House leaders. Let me be perfectly clear. There was no agreement by House leaders that Thursday was going to be the end of the debate or Monday was going to be the end of the debate. There was no agreement by me and, it is safe to say, by my colleague from the New Democratic Party nor from the government.
We have clearly indicated that there was no agreement that it would be a two-day debate. Let us not have any illusions as to the fact that there was some agreement in the works behind the scenes with regard to a two-day debate.
I want to tell the Chair that on this side of the House there are in excess of 40 members who wish to participate in the debate on this particular bill. I do not want to go through all of the facts which have been put before the Chair.
Does the Chair think it appropriate and fair that we accept a government offer in terms of the debate of this particular bill in the House when the Chair knows, has read and has clearly seen the unfairness of the way in which we proceeded yesterday?
Does the Chair think that is an appropriate option?

Just a moment. I have thanked hon. members for the tone with which this difficult matter has been dealt.
I ask hon. members to understand the position that a Speaker is in given this difficult circumstance. I have indicated that it would be veiy difficult for a Speaker to say that what happened yesterday did not happen.
Whether I think what the government has proposed to the House is fair or otherwise is not for me to say. It is for the House to say.
What I am saying is if we are to find a resolution of this, then it is advisable for hon. members to take the caveat of the Speaker, which has just been given, that the resolution is probably going to have to be found. I am not absolute on this but it is probably going to have to be found by some kind of consensus in the House.
The hon. member for Edmonton Southwest can clarify this, but if there is the proposition on the floor of the House by the government House leader for the House's acceptance of his suggestion, then it can be dealt with. It can either be accepted or it can be rejected. If it is rejected, then I shall have to consider the matter further. Or hon. members may be able to discuss with each other a solution to it. I want to get that clarified.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity-
Having some bit of detachment from the issue, not having been in the House at the time but having had a chance to listen to the argument, I appreciate the quality of the argument we have had here today. My opinion is that there may have been inadvertence on all parts. I do not wish to escalate the debate at all, but I believe it is necessary to put one point forward. If in excess of 40 members were seeking to intervene, why did not one rise to participate in the debate yesterday?
That notwithstanding, I wish to honour the spirit of the undertaking that was given among the House leaders and I believe that the suggestion of the hon. member for Nanaimo-Cowichan is a useful one. I can indicate to the hon. opposition House leader that the government is prepared to discuss the possibility of some extension of hours on Monday, if that would be helpful, and that the six o'clock time for the deferred division need not be set in stone.
It would be very useful to have an opportunity to discuss these matters perhaps during Question Period or as soon as it is convenient and perhaps to get on to other business of the House in the interim.

Mr. Speaker, what happened yesterday is the object of a question of privilege by the member for Scarborough-Rouge River. That was the first question that we addressed here at ten o'clock. We do not for a
May 1, 1992

moment want to get involved in a debate here on the parliamentary solution between House leaders as to what can be done in terms of a decision by the House, not by the Speaker.
That is very dangerous for us to start negotiating on the floor of the House. When I hear members on the government side making proposals and then changing and modifying their proposals-one additional day on Monday and then extension of hours on Monday-goodness knows what can happen. Then we are going to get involved and it is going to be eleven o'clock and then there will be a problem procedurally.
I want to make it very clear that the question at hand is that yesterday's events in our view were not appropriate in terms of procedure, time constraints and fairness to the opposition side. That is our point.
We are saying to the Chair that there was a question put by the member for Carleton-Gloucester-

I do not want to be arbitrary here. I have listened carefully to the facts. There may be some dispute among members as to what was or what was not said or otherwise, but the facts seem to be relatively clear.
I am not saying for one moment there has not been a question of privilege raised. I am saying that in the midst of it, the House has heard a suggestion by the government which would, if accepted, at least have this debate proceed on Monday.
It may be that the House wants to discuss with the government whether Monday is sufficient or whether there should be a longer time. If that is what is desired by hon. members, then it seems to me appropriate that the discussion take place and hon. members return to the Chair if they have some advice to give me.
The question of privilege, if there is a motion moved, remains with me to deal with. It is not the same issue, it is a second issue. I am trying to assist the House to at least get the debate on again if that is what hon. members want.

I want to address that point. That is what I was trying to address.
If you have to rule as to whether there was a prima facie case of privilege yesterday, we maintain on this side there was such a situation yesterday. It meets with all
Privilege
the rules, regulations, interpretations and historical values of this House.
The member for Carleton-Gloucester rose in his seat and said to the Chair: "Is there not a ten-minute questions and comments period after a speech?" The Chair said it had asked for those questions, which is not what the record shows. There has inadvertently been a mistake which impinged on the privilege of the House which hurt our right to speak.
This is all we have to do here. That is what we are paid to do, for God's sake. We are to debate things and in terms of my privileges and the privileges of members of this caucus, we were yesterday taken for a ride because we were not given that privilege. Nobody asked for debate.
I say to the member from Edmonton that nobody asked. The Speaker he did not say debate. He asked if the House was ready for the question. We were not ready for that question.

Mr. Speaker, I am concerned that this very important question of privilege is being confused in an exchange of you said, I said, we said about private arrangements that are necessary to keep this House going. It would seem to me that any discussion at this particular moment about arrangements between the government and the opposition or the other parties in the House would be out of order at this point.
We are making an appeal to the chair specifically on a point of privilege. I am surprised we would even raise the point that such negotiations would be a part of a point of privilege.
I want to make it very clear that when the Chair feels it has heard all of the evidence on the making of a prima facie case about a matter of privilege, it will inform the House that it has heard that evidence and will, in its wisdom, deal with that evidence. At the same time I do not think the House should be burdened by our own lack of communication or some of it by using the Chair for that communication.
If the Chair became involved in that kind of communication, it would only diminish its role in dealing with a matter of privilege.
The matter of privilege is one of great substance, great importance, and I would urge the Chair not to entertain any discussion at all about arrangements between the parties except to encourage that they do that efficiently, gentlemanly and with some sense of urgency, while at

May 1, 1992
the same time appreciating the very great urgency all of us feel about the Speaker's action yesterday; separating the two points and keeping them separate.

Mr. Speaker, I stress the following two facts. One is that the prima facie case of privilege in my view has been established. The privilege of those who are here today to speak on this bill, who were here yesterday and who may not be available to speak on Monday, would be broken if a time limit were imposed. Therefore the situation as it stood yesterday until five o'clock, namely a debate without time limit, ought to be restored.
Second, in full appreciation of the position of the Chair, it seems to me that your attention has to be drawn once again to the fact, as recorded at page 9945, that the Acting Speaker yesterday at five o'clock failed to ask the question "are there any comments or questions". Elis intervention, as recorded, created the impression for hon. members present in the House that he had actually asked the question.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday, in courtesy to the Chair, I took the decision of the Chair as being final. However, I did feel that I had not been given an opportunity to comment during the five minute question period and that the Chair at that point proceeded anyway.

I am going to conclude debate on this matter, except I am coming back to the hon. member for Scarborough-Rouge River. I take it I will have a motion from the hon. member. The hon. member should rise and read that motion. Is the hon. member prepared to move the appropriate motion? Without it I am left with nothing.
Mr. Speaker, I am of course prepared to move a motion articulating the breach of privilege I just put to the House.

I thank the hon. member. I shall do the best I can with it.
It being 11 o'clock a.m., pursuant to Standing Order 30(5), the House will now proceed to Statements by Members pursuant to Standing Order 31.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Forestry
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would draw the attention of the House to an important initiative of the federal government that was announced yesterday. It is Tree Plan Canada, a national community tree-planting program that will give Canadians the opportunity to make their own contribution to solving environmental problems.
The national launch of this program will be followed by regional events as part of National Trees and Forests Week, May 3 to 9. Tree Plan Canada, a forestry program of Canada's green plan, will show the practical and environmental benefits of planting trees.
This program gives Canadians a chance to become familiar with their forest heritage and also help improve our environment, for which we all have a great responsibility. Tree Plan Canada encourages various associations and organizations to work together in partnership on tree-planting projects.
Tree Plan Canada is the second forestry program of the green plan. In September 1991, the federal government announced the Partners for Sustainable Forest Development Program, which is in three main parts: model forests, the improvement-

speechtext: I am sorry to interrupt the hon. member. The hon. member for Carleton-Gloucester has the floor.

Madam Speaker, what a fine victory for Canada.
A French Canadian from Ontario, yes, Ontario, won first prize in the world French spelling dictation competition held at the United Nations in New York on April 11.
Eric Vovan of Gloucester in my riding did all of Canada proud. He also brought honour to Ontario's French-language school system and the teachers in Ottawa area schools, like Pauline Vanier Primary School, De La Salle Secondary School and the University of Ottawa. He is a credit to the organizers of French
May 1, 1992

competitions in Ontario and their founder, Dr. Robert Gauthier.
I say congratulations and thanks to Mr. Vovan, a Franco-Ontarian. I also congratulate Quebec on coming second in this prestigious world competition.

Madam Speaker, this week is National Volunteer Week. Each year more than 13 million Canadians volunteer their time and talents to help others.
I would like to take this opportunity to make special mention and extend my sincere thanks and gratitude to the many volunteers who take part in Revenue Canada Taxation's community volunteer programs.
The program, now in its 21st year, links volunteers with people who for one reason or another have difficulty completing their income tax returns. In my riding of Bramalea-Gore-Malton, well over 1,000 people have been assisted by approximately 75 volunteers. Last year over 8,000 volunteers helped more than 200,000 people.
All indications are that this year our program will be even bigger. None of this would be possible without the generous spirit of our Canadian volunteers.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, when the Prime Minister took office on that now infamous day in 1984, he promised jobs, jobs, jobs.
When the Prime Minister launched the free trade initiative, he promised prosperity and economic development for all. Reality is far removed from Conservative promises.
In 1992 unemployment hovers at 10 to 11 per cent nationally and is not projected to decline over the next year. Even worse, unemployment in my riding of Kingston and the Islands, according to the most recent Canada Employment Centre statistics lurks at the oppressive rate of 13.3 per cent.
Where are the jobs? Where is the prosperity? It is nowhere to be found. They were but hollow promises of
Conservative hucksters. In the next election the people of Canada and the people of Kingston and the Islands will remember this government's legacy: "No jobs, no jobs, no jobs".

Madam Speaker, the issue of Macedonia has become a source of disquiet and great concern for Canadians of Greek origin. This is only natural since for many of my constituents the issue of Macedonia is not a simple matter of name but a fundamental element of their Hellenic culture and history.
According to the historical record, the Macedonia "republic" of Yugoslavia only came into existence in 1944.

I am well aware that this issue is not easy. I also know that the Minister of External Affairs is following the whole situation and Canadians of Greek origin trust the minister and her officials.
As I often say, when I was studying Greek in my student years, Macedonia certainly was a name found in my books of Greek literature.

Madam Speaker, failed justice has once again ignited the flammable tinder box of racism and social injustice in America.
We must deplore the violence displayed by those of all colours in Los Angeles, but we must also recognize that a jury's racist conclusion, that the frightful reality of our senses was a delusionary image, was just one of many possible sparks to an explosion inevitable among those kept poor, alienated and excluded from the American dream.
Theirs has been a nightmare of denial by an ethic of greed, privilege and the hedonistic pursuit of wealth by the few at the expense of fairness, equity and justice for the many.

May 1, 1992
Canada is not free of racism. It is not free of injustice. But thank God Canada is not America. Let us be warned that the pursuit of a Reaganite or Bush agenda could make us so. If we are to pursue a social and economic level playing field, let Canada be the standard, not America.
