Madam Speaker, National Volunteer Week is a very good time to reflect on the tremendous contribution of volunteers to Canadian society. Many programs and services that our country depends on are supported by volunteers. Volunteerism is an essential force in community life and enriches practically all aspects of our society.
For this reason, I would like to mention in particular the work done by an organization in Joliette, the Groupe entraide benevole Emilie-Gamelin. The purpose of this group is to care for seniors in their homes so that they can remain there longer instead of living in an institution. The services provided by this group go from meal preparation to household maintenance.
The Groupe entraide benevole Emilie-Gamelin exists only because of the hard work of its volunteers, and I ask the people of my riding to give enthusiastic support to the work these men and women do for our senior citizens.

Madam Speaker, it is with pride that I rise today to recognize the efforts of a true leader in the community of Ottawa South as we strive to affirm the ties that make this a united country.
Rabbi Reuven Bulka of the Congregation Machzikei Hadas has called upon his fellow clergy across all denominations to make a firm statement in favour of Canada.
The initiative called "Clergy for a United Canada" has to date received support from over 4,350 members of the clergy from across Canada, including 446 from the province of Quebec.
These individuals have signed a declaration calling upon the constitutional participants to make national unity their first priority. The Clergy for a United Canada has also adopted the use of a common prayer, asking for God's guidance that we will preserve the goodiness that is Canada.
On behalf of my colleagues, I salute the efforts of Rabbi Bulka and his fellow clergy and join them in their prayer that God will grant us the wisdom to succeed.

Madam Speaker, to mark Volunteer Week which ends tomorrow, our Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs, the member for Bellechasse, rightly said: "It is well known that volunteerism keeps many organizations going and makes a major contribution to the Canadian economy."
I too would like to thank personally all the people of Abitibi who make our region and this great country better with their volunteer work.

Madam Speaker, this week marked a day on the Jewish calendar designated Yom Hasoah Vehagvurah, the Holocaust remembrance day. It is a reminder of when, just after Passover in 1943, the Jews of the Warsaw ghetto, sick and starving as they were, rose up against their Nazi oppressors, battling them for 42 days until the ghetto was liquidated.
The uprising remains a profound testimony to the strength of human spirit and the bravery of those fighters who were determined to die unconquered. This same strength of spirit was shared by six million Jews, including one million children, who were murdered at the hands of the Nazis and their collaborators. This day also
May 1, 1992

gives us another special moment to say of the Holocaust, of the Shoah and its legacy of hate "never again".
As we begin shaping a united Canada for the next 125 years, let us make the fight against racism, xenophobia and intolerance part of the Canadian fabric by sharing our many wonderful and diverse cultures, languages and traditions. In so doing, we can rekindle that sense of common purpose which will guide Canadians in that most noble of endeavours, building a strong, united, democratic Canada for all our children and grandchildren.

Madam Speaker, yesterday's Ontario budget increased the provincial income tax rate from 53 to 55 per cent, effectively cancelling out for Ontario residents the federal budget reduction in personal income taxes. So much for stimulating consumer spending and creating jobs by cutting taxes.
The same thing happened in 1988 when our government cut federal income taxes and the then Peterson government in Ontario nullified the cut by raising provincial income taxes.
This should be a lesson for all those who advocate further decentralization and even greater powers for provincial governments in our current constitutional discussions. Diametrically opposite federal and provincial fiscal policies like those announced in Ontario yesterday could very well produce economic chaos in our country.

Madam Speaker, the Canadian Task Force on Literacy estimated that illiteracy in Canadian workers costs Canadian businesses $4 billion a year in lost revenues.
The Economic Council of Canada, which will be axed by Bill C-63, urges governments, employers and schools to co-ordinate their efforts to eliminate functional
illiteracy and better prepare young people for productive employment.
The federal government must provide leadership if Canada's 28 per cent illiteracy rate is to be reduced by the year 2000. School dropouts, functionally illiterate adults and immigrants need accessible community learning centres and trained tutors and counselling services.
I urge the government to increase funding to expand community programs and on the job learning opportunities. The National Literacy Secretariat should be expanded to assist governments to achieve the goals outlined by the Economic Council of Canada.
An investment in literacy must be a top priority to achieve a more productive Canada.

Madam Speaker, yesterday the Ontario NDP presented its budget. I note that Ontario is attempting to address its deficit problem and is working toward expenditure restraint.
Bob Rae has a long way to go. It is a measure of how badly managed the Ontario finances are when a treasurer can peddle a $10 billion deficit and a $1 billion increase in new taxes as a triumph of fiscal balance.
My constituents are disappointed in the personal income tax increases. The NDP essentially is taxing back the personal income tax benefits in the recent federal budget. Once again the NDP is focusing on government expenditure to stimulate job creation.
The socialists say: "Spend $9 billion over four years and create 90,000 jobs". Would it be fair to ask how many jobs are lost when $1.1 billion annually is taken out of taxpayers' pockets?

Madam Speaker, on Wednesday, February 5, 1992 I presented two petitions to the House in relation to the death of Nina de Villiers.
The disappearance and tragic deaths of four young ladies in my area and the immediate neighbouring cities

May 1, 1992
Oral Questions
have spread fear and concern about the safety of citizens in our cities, and more particularly the safety of young women who have become victims of violent crimes.
Today we mourn the loss of another bright, young student of St. Catharines. The body of Kristen French who has been missing for two weeks, a student at Holy Cross High School, has been found and there are suggestions that she may have died violently. I am sure that all members would want to join with me in extending our heartfelt sympathies to the surviving French family.
I urge the Minister of Justice to consider using the resources of the federal government to complement the efforts of the provincial and regional authorities to restore peace and safety in our region.

Madam Speaker, all Canadians congratulate the people of the Regional Municipality of Sudbury on the announcement that our municipality has been selected as one of the 12 finalists in the honours program of the UNCED Local Government Honours Program.
The presentation will take place in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil on June 3, 1992. The region is also one of five winners of the 1992 Chevron conservation awards in the United States.
There is no doubt that Sudbury has earned this honour. The revitalization program started in the late 1970s when laid-off workers were employed in projects to plant grass and seedlings on the moonscape of the Sudbury region.
This project involved local, provincial and federal governments, as well as local mining companies and post-secondary institutions. We all share the pride of the people of the Sudbury region in having been recognized for their efforts to refurbish the environment which previous logging and mining practices had destroyed.
The people of the Sudbury region fully deserve this distinction for their efforts in environmental restoration.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would like to ask a question of the Deputy Prime Minister.
We understand that the Prime Minister is travelling in western Canada. Looking at his program, it is photo op, photo op, photo op, photo op, photo op.
I would like to know from the Minister of Finance if he has informed the Prime Minister that there are 13,000 people unemployed in Williams Lake, representing 14 per cent of the population of this district. In Dawson Creek and the Chetwynd district 8,000 people are unemployed, representing 12.4 per cent of the population. In Kamloops, a city that was so prosperous some years ago, there are 10,000 people unemployed today, representing almost 17 per cent of the population.
I would like to know from the Deputy Prime Minister if this government realizes that the people there are not looking for photo opportunities. They are looking for job opportunities and they need these jobs right now.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I think the hon. member would share the view that the economy of British Columbia is probably one of the stronger economies in Canada at the present time.
It too has been affected by the world-wide slowdown, by low commodity prices. It is primarily a resource based economy, particularly the communities to which my hon. friend refers. Those communities are largely dependent upon the resource sector.
There has been price depression, but I can assure the hon. member that we have taken initiatives in the budget to improve the competitive position of Canada and to put in place the fundamentals so that interest rates continue to come down. They have come down and they are staying down. There has been a moderation of interest rates of over 7 per cent since the high of 1990. Those sectors to which I referred earlier are interest rate sensitive.
May 1, 1992

Oral Questions
We have also provided incentives to stimulate the housing sector. We have provided incentives to improve the competitiveness of the manufacturing and processing sector. That is where the jobs are created.
I think my hon. friend will be encouraged by the fact that there seems to be a pick up in the United States. The secretary of the treasury indicated at the G-7 meetings this past week that he is convinced the U.S. economy has turned the corner.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is not an answer the minister is giving us; it is an excuse.
I would like the Prime Minister while travelling to show some seriousness. We saw him this morning wearing some cowboy boots, trying to show off, when we know that he is more comfortable in Gucci slippers. The Prime Minister should know that real western cowboys know the bull when they see it.
I would like to know from this minister when the government will get serious, stop these photo opportunities at the expense of the taxpayers, and deal with the problem that this nation faces today with 1.5 million people unemployed.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, if the hon. Leader of the Opposition were serious when he posed his question it would command a serious response.
Notwithstanding that fact, I will respond in a serious manner because he knows and understands that not only Canada is experiencing a slowdown. The IMF has adjusted downward the growth of the G-7 countries to 1.7 per cent, coming out of a very slow and weak period in the world economy. That certainly does not augur well for stimulating the activity here in Canada, because Canada is indeed a trade dependent nation.
We are part of the world global trading community. We obviously have to be there to ensure that we can participate in a competitive way when things pick up.
The budget that I brought down in February is a budget that does provide the framework for improving our competitiveness, for job creation, a continuation of the macroeconomic policy of sustained growth with price stability, containment of inflation, containment of inflationary expectations and fiscal consolidation. That is the policy that will work.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the Minister of Finance can say all he wants, but some people in Canada are not working. What are the mayor of Williams Lake, the mayor of Kamloops and the mayor of Montreal asking the Minister of Finance for now? Something quite simple: a program where the federal government would pay a third, the provincial governments would pay a third and they would be ready to start tomorrow by paying another third to put hundreds and thousands of Canadians to work.
Why does the Minister of Finance not grant the wish of these people who want to put Canadians to work and revive the Canadian economy?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the difference between the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition is that the Prime Minister is out meeting and discussing the very fundamental and important issues of the Canadian economy with the people themselves, not chirping away here in Ottawa from on high as if he had all the answers.
The fact of the matter, very simply put, is that the hon. Leader of the Opposition is asking this government to impose a $3 billion tax burden on the backs of Canadians. They are not prepared for that today.

Madam Speaker, a constituent of the Minister of Finance gave me some indications of what his policy is doing across the minister's own constituency this morning.
MacLeod's store in Vegreville, as the minister knows, closed about two months ago. The News Advertiser in Vegreville is full of ads for farm auctions, close-out auctions. Renn-Vertec, a 15-year old grain drier manufacturer in Vermilion, closed down a year ago putting a hundred people out of work. Septre Resources closed its Vegreville office three months ago. The Federal Student Employment Program, which used to employ in the county of Vegreville about a dozen students, now can employ only two. When will the minister get the point? What will he tell his constituents about what his fight

Oral Questions
inflation only, his high interest and his high dollar policies are doing to them?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I do not have to be lectured by the hon. member who probably has never visited Vegreville, at least on a regular basis as I do every weekend. I do not have to be lectured by him. I go back there every weekend and I speak to the people.
Yes, times are difficult, but the fact of the matter is that this government has taken a very important initiative in building with the provinces of Saskatchewan and Alberta a heavy oil upgrader that will provide not only job opportunities and improved operating conditions for the oil sector but will particularly provide security of supply. We have supported agriculture in an unprecedented fashion, probably about $30 billion of direct support to the agricultural community in very difficult times.
What we have done in the budget is improve the competitiveness and the investment opportunities for the manufacturing and processing sector. I am sure the hon. member is aware that in Alberta today 25 per cent of the Gross Domestic Product is derived from manufacturing and processing. That is where the jobs are created. That is where the economic activity can be created. That is where the opportunities lie and that is what we are addressing.

Madam Speaker, as a matter of fact I bought my cowboy boots in Vegreville, and I hope that store is still open.
Statistics Canada says that there have been almost 5,000 consumer and business bankruptcies in western Canada. Canadian mining companies are expected to invest about $750 million in Chile by 1994 because of a more favourable climate, and 800,000 jobs in the oil and gas industry have been lost since 1985.
When will the minister get the point? The government's deflationary policies are wreaking havoc in every comer of this country except in the banking sector.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I know the hon. member would like to see this government reimpose the National Energy Program. That is what he has been advocating for quite some time.
The government removed the constraints in the energy sector by removing the burden of taxes on the energy
sector: the PGRT, the incremental oil revenue tax, the natural gas and gas liquid tax, and the Canadian ownership charge. All those taxes were a legacy of the Liberal government and the Liberal Party of which he is a member.
Yes, look around the world and find that rationalization has taken place in the United States and other places. Commodity prices have come down. That is very true.
I remind the hon. member that this government took a leap of faith in investing very heavily in the heavy oil upgrader which provides opportunities for the future and not only security of supply.

Madam Speaker, my question relates to not only existing job losses but the potential job losses that are looming because this government does not seem to be firm enough in dealing with trade issues.
My question for the Minister for International Trade, or whoever is speaking for international trade today, is about the decision by GATT which says that the United States has indeed been subsidizing American breweries to the threat of 18,000 brewery workers in Canada.
The United States has agreed that the GATT panel ruling is correct and has sent a spin-out to press suggesting that it will correct the problem of subsidies by the middle of June, that is next month.
I want to ask the government if it has received a letter from the U.S. state department confirming that it is the U.S. government's position to meet next June as a deadline for eliminating these subsidies and that all the states involved and all the breweries involved will put in writing that they too agree with this decision. If not, words will not mean anything.

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockiu (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I had a little trouble discerning a question in all that. Let me respond to the hon. member's remarks on the GATT panel decision on the U.S. barriers against beer. This particular announcement of yesterday is very good news for us. It confirms what we have argued, which is that they have a number of barriers against exports of Canadian beer, a number of barriers against Canadian exports of wine. As a matter of
May 1, 1992

fact, there are over 60 different barriers to trade in 39 different states. We have fought this protectionism in the GATT context. We have prevailed and the panel has confirmed that.
In June the U.S. will be formally responding, but it is going to have to respond in a way which will deal with the questions posed by the hon. member and the criticisms we have brought to the GATT panel.

Madam Speaker, no one is disputing that GATT has proven what this government and other governments have said before. The GATT panel has clearly stated that the U.S. is in violation.
What I am asking the minister is not further talk from the United States. I ask the minister this specific question: Has the government received, in writing, confirmation that the United States Government will act according to this panel's ruling by the middle of next month and order the states and order the breweries to comply with this ruling?
Thlk is one thing. I want to know if this government has received in writing a commitment from the United States to meet the June deadline.

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I share with the hon. member his impatience that we should get that sort of communication, but he has to know how GATT works. There are these milestones, They are all voluntary milestones. He does not really care how it works. The GATT procedures are there as voluntary complying milestones.
What we expect in June is that the whole range of criticisms made by the GATT panel will be agreed to by the U.S. If it will not, we will take our retaliatory steps.

Madam Speaker, this is only the tip of the foam, so to speak. The reality is that the minister has now admitted that this government does not have a firm position, saying that he hopes the United States will voluntarily comply. It has not voluntarily complied on one single dispute to
Oral Questions
this date. Since we signed the free trade agreement, it has even snubbed its nose more at this government.
There are 18,000 jobs involved here. I am asking the minister to tell the Canadian people that this government will insist, in writing, from the U.S. administration right now that it intends to comply or else tell the Americans: "The agreement you made last week is no longer valid. Either put up or shut up". Waiting for conversation is only going to drive people to drink and it will be American beer not Canadian beer if this government does not take some action.
Spoken like a true expert on beer.

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, this strutting and fretting that the hon. member is going through is all very impressive. I can assure him that the Canadian government will pin the U.S. down on all of these matters. As a matter of fact, it is very much in their interest to co-operate because they have a panel finding into Canada which means they have an incentive to comply.
The hon. member mentions how important it is to tell the Americans what to do in this particular case. He has been telling the House of Commons, month after month, how useless it is to have a free trade agreement. We have, in fact, backing up the GATT panels and the GATT resolution mechanisms, also another dispute settlement mechanism we can use when we have disputes with the United States. Already we have had 18 dispute panels with the U.S. We have won nine and we have lost nine. We have equality with the U.S. whenever we have a dispute, even though we are one tenth the size of their economy.
Therefore, we now have additional resources to use against the U.S. when disputes like this occur.

Madam Speaker, my question is to the Deputy Prime Minister. Yesterday in Chetwynd, B.C. the Prime Minister announced a $75 million beautification with trees program for communities across Canada, but nothing for the silvicultural industry.

May 1, 1992
Oral Questions
Last year when the forest resource development agreements were renewed, B.C.'s was reduced from $300 million to $200 million; Ontario's from $30 million to $12 million.
As a result, 150 million seedlings will not be planted this year. This is obscene. Will the minister initiate talks immediately with his provincial counterparts in order to rectify this situation?

speakeroldname: Mr. Michel Champagne (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Forestry):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Forestry
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the hon. member referred to the fact that yesterday in Chetwynd, the Prime Minister announced funding totalling $75 million in new money for reforestation, the so-called beautification with trees program.
I think that Ontario, like all Canadian provinces, will benefit handsomely as a result of this new funding which is in addition to the reforestation program agreements already signed with the provinces.
I may remind the hon. member that under the Constitution, management of natural resources is a strictly provincial responsibility, and that the federal government, through the Department of Forestry, is doing more than its fair share to help the provinces deal with problems relating to reforestation and research and development.
I think the hon. member will acknowledge that the efforts of the Minister of Forestry in this respect have been considerable and that those efforts are continuing.

Madam Speaker, the silviculture industry in Canada will find little solace in the hon. member's answer, especially at a time when all forest reports indicate that we are seriously lagging behind in reforestation, especially at a time when thousands of workers will be laid off again, especially at a time when Canadians are demanding that reforestation be made a priority.
Will the government financially support its sustainable development policy and fully restore the reforestation program?

speakeroldname: Mr. Michel Champagne (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Forestry):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Forestry
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, again, the hon. member will recall that in early March, the Canadian Council of Forestry Ministers, together with environmental groups, the industry and all parties with a stake in the development of our forests, met here in Ottawa. There was a common front to support sustainable development, and furthermore, the federal forestry department is committed to a number of agreements, including one in British Columbia, where the hon. member says there is a reforestation problem. In B.C., the number of trees being planted now exceeds the number being cut. Another example is Quebec, where, after the initial reforestation program, we are now going to maintain the trees that have been planted.
I think the government is doing a great deal, and once again, I would like to remind the hon. member that although the funding available may not be adequate in every respect, we are working very hard with the provinces to provide programs that will help deal with most of these problems and make Canada's forests productive and competitive on all markets.

Madam Speaker, with reference to the GATT rulings on beer, the minister knows very well that there have been two rulings: one is a ruling affecting Canadian exports of beer to the United States and the other is American beer exported to Canada.
Can the government state clearly today that Canadian brewers will have equal access to the U.S. market and on the same date that U.S. brewers will gain free access to the Canadian market?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, in reality what we want is far better than what the hon. member is asking for.
Can he just follow this logic. Let us say at present, roughly we have 1 per cent of the U.S. beer market. If we doubled our access to the U.S. beer market to 2 per cent that would be, if he wants to check his figures, 60 million more cases of beer exported into the U.S. from Canada than with 1 per cent of the market.
May 1, 1992

If the U.S. doubled its exports into the Canadian market, which is now about 3 per cent, and doubled it to 6 per cent, it would have 12 million additional cases.
What we want to accomplish is the same access to the U.S. as it has to Canada which would give us five times more exports than it would have into Canada.

Madam Speaker, surely the minister does not regard that as a serious answer to a serious question.
Let me ask the minister this. In light of the GATT rulings, the government has stated that it is seeking to remove interprovincial trade barriers in the beer industry by 1993. That is just one sector where interprovincial trade barriers are a major impediment to Canada's competitiveness internationally. Can the minister indicate the government's commitment today to ensure all interprovincial trade barriers are removed so Canada in a global trading world can compete effectively?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the hon. member wants us to discipline the Canadian context. Of course, we will work toward what he is asking for which is the removal of interprovincial barriers.
More important, here is what we are working for through access to the U.S. We are going to do away with discriminatory tax measures which favour local beers in 39 different states in the U.S. We are going to do away with discriminatory distribution practices in 22 different states in the U.S. We are going to do away with discriminatory licence fees. We are going to do away with our practice of exempting locally produced wines from decisions to prohibit the sale of alcoholic beverages in a number of their states. We are going to do away with a whole number of discriminatory pricing practices that exist in the U.S. That is the great news of yesterday's panel decision.

Madam Speaker, my question is to the Deputy Prime Minister.
Oral Questions
The recent GATT beer ruling again draws attention to the very large subsidies and general level of market and trade interference that takes place at the state level in the United States.
Given that Canada-U.S. trade negotiations began seven years ago and the current three country negotiations three years ago, can the minister explain why no department of this government has yet produced a report on the full extent of American agricultural subsidization at the state and federal levels?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is a good question. I want to assure the hon. member, and I think he is aware of this, that while I occupied the position of Minister of Agriculture we did take steps to do a complete and thorough analysis of at least a number of the more important agriculture states to determine the level of support and the way in which that support was provided to the producers so we could get a better assessment of the kind of support that was being provided and whether it had a distortive effect on the competitive position.
I am sure the hon. member understands this is more complex than we had originally thought. I believe the first interim report that was provided by the consulting company required that additional work had to be done. I expect there will be that compilation completed very soon. I will check and get back to the hon. member with a precise date.

Madam Speaker, the current Minister of Agriculture has left the impression that his department does not have the ability nor the capacity to do such investigations and has long after the fact received the report of Hill and Knowlton to which the Deputy Prime Minister referred.
There is another study going on under the aegis of the Canadian Grains Council which should have been reported three or four months ago but we are still waiting for it.
Will the Deputy Prime Minister explain to the House why his government cannot find within its own departments the capability of doing such work or our trade in agriculture irritants has such a low priority they have to go outside the country to find these bits of information.

May 1, 1992
Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, no they are not a low priority. The fact we have undertaken such a study is clear evidence of the fact. There are a number of supports that are quite clearly evident, there are others that require further work. For example, the CITT assessment of the fruit industry identified the kind of measures of support that puts Canadian fruit producers at a competitive disadvantage. It is a complex issue.
It is quite true as I said, the initial report from Hill and Knowlton has been provided. My understanding is further work is being done. It is important to clearly identify the kind and level of programs and support systems that are in place and it is equally important to maintain a timely and updated data base and that is exactly what we have been trying to do.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the acting Minister of Industry, Science and Technology. Yesterday I asked the government to implement strict environmental regulations in order to create a strong domestic market as an incentive to develop new environmental technologies. The minister's answer was just to mention a small program and wash his hands of the matter.
Why does the government want Canada to be content with always importing technology from others instead of becoming a major exporter?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am interested and I agree with the thrust of the hon. member's question that we should have an environmental regime which encourages the development of a number of technologies in this country which we adapt to and then can export all over the world.
The trouble with his question is that we are already doing that. As a country we have federally inspired a number of environmental regulations which have given rise to a number of technological adaptations to dealing
with environmental problems. As a result of that we have exports of Canadian environmental technologies all over the world.
There is a firm in my riding, Trojan Technologies, which purifies water. It was put in place in a large measure by an environmental context and it is exporting to 80 different countries around the world.
There are lots of examples. I do not think that he should disparage the answer of the minister of science yesterday who reminded the House that we have a program for technological adaptation for export especially in relation to environmental products of over $100 million. That program has helped with hundreds of companies and we are doing exactly what the hon. member is asking us to do. He is just three or four years late with his question.

If that is the case, Madam Speaker, then the entire environmental technology industry is three or four years late.
This week they said that the single biggest inhibitor to the development of environmental technologies is the fact that this government is five to ten years behind the Americans, who are five to ten years behind the Germans and the Japanese.
What is very clear to everybody who has been involved in this is what is driving the world's leaders, the U.S., the Japanese, and the Germans, is the development of environmental regulations on the cutting edge of new technologies, regulations that we will eventually have to adapt to and adopt when it is too late.
Given the failure of the Minister of the Environment to push for these kinds of regulations, will the minister of industry instead of hiding in some kind of cocoon take the environmental lead right across the industrial spectrum so that we in this country can develop the jobs of tomorrow in the industries of tomorrow?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, this is one of the most curious questions ever posed in the House.
Essentially, what he is asking is that the Government of Canada, almost regardless of environmental need, concoct endless regulations and red tape in order to develop industries. This is the Liberal backward way of stimulating an economy.
May 1, 1992

What we believe we should do is regulate the environment for environmental purposes, not to create technologies but regulate them for environmental purposes.
What you do to create technologies is adapt them of course to some regulations, but you also try to encourage them as we are through the Department of Industry, Science and Technology. There are six different panels that are studying this, that are producing programs, that are delivering assistance to environmental technology firms. We are doing this in a positive way rather than in a backward negative way, as proposed by the hon. member.

Madam Speaker, today in New York last ditch negotiations are being held for a global warming convention. The United States is alone in refusing to sign an accord which would set specific targets for reducing carbon dioxide emissions.
In view of the fact that the convention is in peril of becoming a meaningless accord without a specific commitment by the United States of America, I would like to ask the Deputy Prime Minister whether he will listen to the advice offered by the National Round Table on the Environment and the Economy. Will he urge the Prime Minister of Canada not to sign in Rio the proposed convention unless specific targets and timetables are included in this convention?

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I cannot help but notice a slight difference between the question just asked by the hon. member and that of his seatmate who just 30 seconds ago was lauding the fact that the Americans tend to be a leader and suggested we should indeed follow in their footsteps.
The hon. member just made the point that Canada has been a leader with respect to providing leadership in the area of global warming and is urging us to exert some influence upon the United States.
It is true that Canadian representatives have played a very significant role in the negotiations leading up to Rio and it is true the Prime Minister has indicated that he will be one of the world leaders attending that particular conference. In fact, we think it is important that he showed sufficient interest in the environment to accept
Oral Questions
that responsibility and to take the opportunity to provide that leadership.
We hope that the example of Canada and other nations will help persuade the Americans to accept what we would consider to be, as the hon. member does, a very important role on their part.
The problems facing the environment are indeed global in nature and they can only be addressed adequately when the entire global community responds.

Madam Speaker, I thank the parliamentary secretary for his answer and I want to remind him that in 1989 the Prime Minister of Canada made a very strong declaration on behalf of Canada in The Hague for the protection of the quality of the atmosphere.
Therefore, I ask him will the Government of Canada live up to the statement of the Prime Minister of Canada in 1989 and commit Canada to a reduction of 20 per cent in carbon dioxide emissions by the year 2005?

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, as you know, Canada has been one of several nations that have accelerated their timetables which are already in place with respect to the deletion, the non-use, the non-importation of certain damaging products. We have in a very real sense taken second place to no one in that regard.
As one of my hon. colleagues has just suggested, I should remind the House of the very important innovation announced yesterday in British Columbia by the Prime Minister with respect to the Tree Plan Canada program, as I believe it is called.
There are a number of measures put in place. As the hon. member knows, the Canadian government has accelerated timetables that have been in place for several years. We have done that in co-operation with other ministries.
It is important to remember that all members of this government must work together to achieve these timetables. But it is also exceedingly important that the provinces be in co-operation with that, and industry, and various other organizations. The key approach is a co-operative one and we are doing a good job in that regard.

May 1, 1992
Oral Questions FISHERIES

Madam Speaker, my question is to the minister of tourism.
The government's mismanagement of the east coast fishery is well known. Now there is potential for the same mismanagement in the Great Lakes.
The minister should know that lamprey eel are proliferating and destroying the fish stock in the Great Lakes. The U.S.A. has increased lamprey control funding by 18 per cent this year and a promise of 12 per cent next year, while Canada is not even meeting its funding obligations arising from a Canada-U.S. agreement struck in 1955.
I know that the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans is most concerned. Has he asked his colleague to announce that Canada will fulfil its long-standing obligation to preserve the fishing industry in the Great Lakes?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
I thank the hon. member for his question.
It is certainly true that zebra mussels, lamprey eel and all these other threats to the Great Lakes are very important. As a matter of fact, they are important to our commercial fishery as well as our recreational fishery. The recreational fishery is a tremendous job creator and I think that is why he looks at it as an important tourism component.
I have to tell him that the health of the Great Lakes has greatly improved. We have now unequalled stocks of trout and salmon in the Great Lakes that we did not have before. The sport fishery is growing enormously in Ontario in particular because of this.
I do not want to be complacent but I should tell my hon. friend that he should be brought up to date on how these fish stocks are improving. We are going to work to make sure that continues in the future.

I appreciate the lesson. But this morning lamprey eel control individuals indicated that one in five trout in northern Lake Huron are wounded by the lamprey eel. So I do not accept the minister's admonition.
This is an embarrassment for Canadians who work in the field. They are meeting in Washington next week with their hats in their hands again, asking the Americans to help us. The American 18 per cent increase is going to American waterways only. The lamprey eels are spawning now.
Will the minister ask the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans to reconsider the $2.3 million expenditure? That is all it would take to preserve a $1.4 billion annual sport and commercial fishing industry in the Great Lakes.

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I certainly will talk to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans to find out the whole array of things that we can do to address the problem the hon. member raises. I hope he will speak to the provincial Government of Ontario as well.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.
In his February budget, the minister announced a cut in federal personal income taxes. Yesterday, the Ontario provincial government announced an increase in the provincial personal income taxes.
What is the combined impact of the federal personal income tax cut and the provincial personal income tax increase on a resident of Ontario? Is this not exactly the same sort of situation that occurred in 1988?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, obviously the tax hit that has been imposed on the personal income tax sector is going to have the effect of undermining consumer confidence further still. It is a $1.1 billion hit which will affect some 4.9 million taxpayers.
The tax break that the federal government provided in the last budget would amount to a $640 million tax relief for Ontario citizens in 1993.
For 1993, the measures in the Ontario budget will have a negative effect of $825 million so that there will be a net negative effect of $285 million. That does not augur well at a time when we are trying to build consumer confidence and at a time when we are trying to encourage and stimulate consumer spending.
May 1, 1992

I hope that Bobbie Rae and his people will take another look at this.

Madam Speaker, in announcing a miserly 37 cent increase per month in the basic old age pension, the Minister of National Health and Welfare did not mention anything about the spouse's allowance or the guaranteed income supplement. I want to ask the government whether that omission was intentional.
Did the government know that the cheques those old age pensioners who qualify for the guaranteed income supplement or the spouse's allowance and whose only other income is the Canada pension received this week would be cut all because the government says there was a 5 per cent increase last year in the Canada pension and that the cost of living in Canada really did not go up for the last six months?
Could the government explain that to our senior citizens?

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I thank the hon. member for his question. One thing we all realize has to do with the rate of inflation and how it affects the country from coast to coast.
Whether you are paying personal income tax, or whether it is a corporation, inflation is at its lowest rate in 20 years. Indeed OAS is indexed according to the CPI. It reflects the direct fall in the inflationary figures.
This is one thing that has been recognized not only by the IMF and the World Bank but also by the OECD. It is what is going to assist us to get out of our difficulties.

Madam Speaker, MPs and regional offices of National Health and Welfare are being inundated today with irate callers, old age pensioners, who are asking why their income supplements and their spouse's allowance have been cut.
Does the government not feel ashamed that it has now short-changed the very segment of our society which least deserves it and which can least afford it, our senior citizens?
Oral Questions
I want to ask the government where do those so-called experts live who claim that the cost of living in Canada has not gone up in the last six months? Where do they live? In Her Majesty's penitentiary?

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I do not consider that last remark funny. Senior citizens are extremely important to this country. There is a bill in this House which says that OAS is indexed according to CPI.
While you think you may be doing one thing for your audience at home, we are here to see that inflation comes down and we get the deficit and debt under control.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Acting Prime Minister and it is with respect to the scheduled execution of Canadian Joseph Faulder in Texas next Wednesday.
We know that the Secretary of State for External Affairs has written to the governor asking that this death sentence be commuted to life imprisonment, but in Texas commutations are handled by a board which meets infrequently and which has not recommended clemency once in the last 47 cases.
As a matter of fact, Texas has the highest execution rate in the United States. The government knows that neither Texas nor the United States notified the Canadian government about this case, as required under the Vienna convention, with the result that Mr. Faulder did not get a proper defence at trial.
In the circumstances, would the government contact the governor once more asking that this execution be cancelled and a new trial ordered?

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Landry (Minister for External Relations and Minister of State (Indian Affairs and Northern Development)):
speakerposition: Minister for External Relations; Minister responsible for La Francophonie; Minister of State (Indian Affairs and Northern Development)
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, as my hon. colleague said, the Secretary of State for External Affairs wrote to the Governor of Texas, asking him to commute Mr. Faulder's death sentence to life imprisonment. She did

Point of Order
so for the very reasons that my colleague mentioned, namely that the American authorities seem to have violated the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations by failing to inform Mr. Faulder of his right to consult a representative of the Canadian government and therefore his family.
I think that the Secretary of State for External Affairs made the appropriate demands and of course we hope that her appeal will be heard.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: I would appreciate the hon. member putting a short supplementary so we can have a single question after from the hon. member for York-ton-Melville to close Question Period.

Madam Speaker, the short question would be that the approach to the governor in Texas should be one not to commute the sentence, but to get a new trial because the defendant did not get a proper trial in the first instance.
Could the minister once again approach the Governor of Texas to cancel the execution and get a new trial, rather than asking for a commutation as she did, because there is very little chance for a commutation but there is a strong chance for a new trial.

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Landry (Minister for External Relations and Minister of State (Indian Affairs and Northern Development)):
speakerposition: Minister for External Relations; Minister responsible for La Francophonie; Minister of State (Indian Affairs and Northern Development)
speechtext: Madam Speaker, Mr. Faulder's case is being appealed in Texas and of course we are following the situation very closely.

Madam Speaker, my question is for the Deputy Prime Minister.
I am sure the Deputy Prime Minister noticed today that Air Canada has announced another lay-off of some 350 people. Most of these are in the management category, but I am also told this morning by the union
that on May 6, Air Canada is going to be meeting the union.
There is a great deal of fear now among the pilots, the flight attendants, the baggage handlers, ticket agents and so on that they are going to hear a very negative announcement on May 6. Perhaps it will be more lay-offs or perhaps more concessions from the people who are going to be working there.
I wonder if the minister is aware of this meeting. If he is aware of it and he knows what is going to happen, can he tell the population of this country today as well as the workers what the situation really is at Air Canada.

Madam Speaker, I am not aware of the particular meeting that the hon. member mentions.
Certainly Air Canada and Canadian as well are having to make very difficult business decisions to ensure that we continue to have two very healthy airlines in this country.
I am sure that the decisions that are made will take into consideration the future of their employees.

Routine Proceedings

Madam Speaker, I have the duty to table five petitions calling upon Parliament to pressure the government to reinstate the Court Challenges Program through which, as we know, several Canadian men and women were able to ask the courts to clarify their linguistic and equality rights under the Constitution.
These five petitions are but a few of many petitions which speak volumes about the determination of the Canadian people to urge government to accede to their request and to reinstate the Court Challenges Program, a program which was costing a mere 10 cents per capita and which gave all Canadians access to justice.

Madam Speaker, I have a petition I would like to present today from my constituents in Lincoln and many within the Hamilton area who believe that there is a need to revise the laws of Canada to replace the Young Offenders Act with an update Juvenile Delinquents Act and a lowering of the maximum age to that of 13 years.

Madam Speaker, I have three different petitions from my constituents. The first is a petition in support of the parents of Nina de Villiers to draw to the attention to the House some shortcomings in the justice system and calls upon Parliament to recognize that crimes of violence against the person are serious and abhorrent to society. They call upon Parliament to amend the Criminal Code, the Bail Reform Act and the Parole Act accordingly.

The second petition points out that applications currently before the CRTC propose the entry into the long distance telephone market of Unitel and that the conditions of entry would provide a regulated cost advantage to the applicants who do not have to supply more costly local telephone service as do other regulated carriers.
Therefore the petitioners urge the Government of Canada to consult with all affected parties, especially rural residents who are at risk of skyrocketing costs for local and long distance telephone calls as a result of this proposed decision.
They call on the government to hold local hearings in rural communities before deciding the fate of our telephone system.

Madam Speaker, the third petition calls upon Parliament to support Canada's rural way of life, to support the maintenance of rural post offices and postal services and to reject the Conservative agenda of cutbacks and closures of those services.

Madam Speaker, I have a petition from several hundred residents of central Vancouver Island in British Columbia which draws to the attention of the House the fact that the United States has unfairly imposed a duty on our softwood lumber that amounts to harassment of Canadian producers.
The petitioners note that the free trade agreement between Canada and the United States has created economic devastation and the loss of jobs instead of providing the promised benefit.
They call upon Parliament to take any action necessary to defend the interests of the Canadian softwood lumber industry against the unfair American duty and call on Parliament to take action immediately to effect the cancellation of the Canada-United States Free Trade Agreement.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to present a petition signed by some 1,627 residents of my constituency and other communities in the adjacent area in British Columbia.
The petitioners say:
We, the residents of the Province of British Columbia, draw to the
attention of the House the following:
That impaired driving offences, alcohol and drug related penalties
are too lenient for these offences are becoming more frequent;
May 1, 1992

That each of these offences harms the public, places heavy burdens on our justice system, health care system and public purse;
There would be fewer such incidents if legislative measures were taken; automatic indefinite licence suspensions, vehicle confiscation for habitual offenders, mandatory blood testing, harsher penalties and plate identification decals for offenders are possible solutions.
Therefore, your petitioners call upon Parliament to enact legislation against impaired driving offenders.

Madam Speaker, my petition is certified correct under Standing Order 36 wherein the petitioners note that the Government of Canada has put forward proposals for amending the Constitution of Canada and that the government has established a citizens' forum to ascertain the views of Canadians on numerous matters and committees to consult with the people of Canada concerning these proposals, whereas the Supreme Court has held that the Constitution of Canada belongs to the people, and whereas the people of Canada believe that consultations should extend to and include approving or disproving Constitution amendments, therefore the petitioners humbly pray and call upon Parliament to enact legislation providing for a referendum of the people, binding upon Parliament, to accept or reject constitutional amendments put forward by the government, and further the acceptance or rejection of the proposed amendments to be determined by a majority of votes of the total votes cast, and a majority vote in a majority of provinces with the territories being given the status of one province.

Madam Speaker, I have the privilege to present some petitions signed by people from all over the city of Toronto which have to do with the refugee system in this country. In the city of Toronto right now we have close to 60,000 refugees. The cost to the taxpayers of Canada is in the hundreds of millions of dollars in terms of the delayed processing of these refugees. It is the legitimate ones I am talking about right now. The delay in processing these claims is causing psychological pain, social pain, not only to the refugees but to all the people in the community where they live. It takes hundreds and hundreds of hours a month from our constituency offices
Routine Proceedings
trying to deal with these complaints. We are calling upon the government to grant a general amnesty to all those people with the exception of those who have criminal records in Canada or criminal records abroad.

speechtext: Madam Speaker, the following questions will be answered today: Nos. 253, 254, 260, and 261.
Did Canada Post Corporation sponsor the Canadian InterUniversity Athletic Union Basketball Championships to be held in March 1992 in Halifax and, if so, what was the total amount of money spent?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Canada Post Corporation has a commitment to participate in local community life and sponsoring an event like the Canadian Inter-University Athletic Union (CIAU) Championships is just one way of doing it. It is also a gesture of support toward amateur sports in Canada.
Canada Post Corporation took the opportunity to promote the stamp dedicated to basketball, which the Canadian Inter-University Athletic Union (CIAU) used as an enlargement as it's official poster for the tournament. This also supports stamp sales revenue objectives.

Very, very briefly, Madam Speaker, the package which is before us today reflects extensive consultations with the multi-level marketing industry. Bill C-68 is, of course, an amendment to the pyramid selling provisions.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Is the hon. parliamentary secretary now rising on debate on Bill C-68? I thought he was on a point of order Is that debate on Bill C-68?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, indeed it is debate and I should have clarified that point. I was proceeding as expeditiously as we had been invited to do.
Multi-level marketing is a product distribution system whereby a participant receives compensation for the supply of a product to any participant in the system who in turn receives compensation for the supply of a product to other participants in the system. There are approximately three-quarters of a million Canadians involved in this industry on a full- or part-time basis. They stand to benefit directly from speedy passage of this substantive amendment.
Before I deal with the technicalities of the proposal, I want to take just a moment to note the support the government has obtained from the two House leaders opposite, and more particularly from the hon. member for Dartmouth and the hon. member for Chambly.

Section 55 of the Competition Act has been a source of confusion for multi-level marketing companies, the public and the courts ever since the legislation was passed in 1976. Because of the problems arising from the section's application, a test case was brought before the Federal Court of Canada in 1980 so that the court could rule on the section's interpretation. In April 1988, the Supreme Court of Canada upheld the interpretation given as to the substance and constitutionality of the section.
The court confirmed the ruling of the Federal Appeal Court that selling schemes that involve payment of a commission for products purchased by participants in the scheme or of commissions for products that continue to be part of the inventory of the recruited participant would be included under the definition of "scheme of pyramid selling" in the legislation.

It was recognized, however, that the existing provision had a number of weaknesses, and discussions were held between the Bureau of Competition Policy and the multi-level marketing industry to improve the legislation. Specifically, the section did not adequately address several practices associated with pyramid selling schemes, such as compensation for recruitment; inventory loading, that is products sold to recruits in unreasonable quantities; required purchases as a condition of entry into a plan; failure to provide the participant with the right to return the product; and, exaggeration of earning potential by disclosing non-representative compensation received by participants.
These practices will now be strictly prohibited.
With the adoption of Bill C-68, consumers who could otherwise have been harmed by deceptive pyramid schemes will be better protected under the Competition Act. As well, industry will benefit from this simplified legislation which will remove some of the uncertainties surrounding the current wording.
Furthermore, all provinces affected by the proposed amendment I have just outlined have been consulted and have responded positively. Clearly, the proposed changes will improve the efficiency and the effectiveness of Canadian competition law as it applies to multi-level marketing.
In conclusion, Madam Speaker, I would like once again to thank my hon. friends opposite for their participation and co-operation in the consultations that have led to the drafting of this timely legislation, as well as to its speedy passage.

Madam Speaker, I would like to start off by congratulating the member for Edmonton Southwest on his new assignment as parliamentary secretary to the government House leader.
It seems that whenever he is involved in legislation in this House it always has a very high road approach, and I think as a result of his style and his approach invariably the legislation that he works on goes through this House in a very expeditious and constructive way. I think as parliamentary secretary to the House leader he will do a terrific job.

As he mentioned, we on this side of the House support this bill. I want to mention that my colleague from Dartmouth, who has worked with the government on this bill for the last little while, has likewise indicated his full support for this amendment to the Competition Act.
I do not think that Canadians realize what a large industry direct marketing is. We are talking about an industry which is close to $8 billion. We are talking about a sector that involves close to 370,000 small businesses engaged in the direct selling business.
As this industry continues to grow, it is very important that the practices be above board. It is important that people who are in the business and have ethics that are above reproach and approved by the direct marketing board get the assurance and the support of this legislation. It is also most important that the consumer is protected because it brings this type of business on to a much higher and a much more sophisticated plane.
I noticed in the legislation that any person who contravenes or goes against this new act is guilty of an offence and subject to a fine at the discretion of the court, or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years and on a summary conviction to a fine not exceeding $25,000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding one year, or both.
This is a pretty strong message to those people who are in this multi-level marketing system, that they make sure their style, their approach, their business ethic meets all of the requirements of this legislation.
This is an interesting way to end this week, putting through legislation in such sort order. Because of the state of the economy right now, I wish that we could bring in similar legislation which would expedite and help other industries in other sectors get on with their business in the same way.
So often the paper burden, red tape and slowness that seems to be attached to the legislation as it involves business in this country is part of the reason our economy has been so sluggish.
Our action today is what Canadians like to see in this House. I wish we could use the process we are using here
Government Orders
today where we put through a bill in such short order in other sectors of the economy.
As I mentioned earlier this week, we have the lowest interest rate that this country has seen in over 20 years, an inflation rate that is virtually eliminated in this country, yet there seems to be this lack of confidence in the marketplace. I said that these are positive facts, that the interest rate and inflation are low. But this lack of confidence is there. Part of that lack of confidence is that we are not sending a signal of leadership on issues that we control here.
We could be using a much more progressive approach in terms of tax reform in this country, especially when it comes to small and medium-sized business and also on the personal side. I guess all of us would concede that this being the week we do our tax returns, more than ever we are reminded of the complexity of the system. Yet we seem to be cautious in attacking the complex system that governs this country in terms of tax reform.
Even though the bill before us today is not complex, there was still the political will on all sides of the House that we clean up this sector of the economy and move the legislation through the House of Commons quickly.
If we could do that in many more areas then the confidence that Canadians innately have but are not showing right now could turn into action. We need to get Canadians feeling good about themselves.
People all over our country must have have had that feeling of total bewilderment as they watched television last night and saw what was happening in Los Angeles. Our neighbours to the south are going through almost a state of anarchy. I do not need to describe it. Every Canadian, I am sure, saw with total and utter amazement what happened in Los Angeles. I, for one, felt so good about Canada last night. I felt so secure and so appreciative of what we have in this country.
There are close to one million Canadians now living in the State of California. Madam Speaker, the New Democrat caucus agreed to this bill going through in one sitting or as has been said, less than half a day, but it is not necessarily the sort of thing that we want to make a habit of.
In this case it is good legislation. It is relatively minor in content yet very important in that it extends consumers' rights and gives consumers the right not to be misled. It deals with multi-level selling. I suppose most
people would know that type of selling better under the term of pyramid selling.
My concern about getting into the habit of passing legislation in one sitting such as this is because of one particular experience in the legislature in British Columbia when we did exactly the same thing. It seemed to be a good change legislatively. It was supported by both parties in the House. There were only two parties in the House at the time. It was done in a hurry in part because it was the last day of sitting before adjournment for the season.
To our chagrin, within 24 hours the legislature had to be recalled for an emergency session. Instead of making one slight change in the operation of a major provincial insurance company, we found out that what we had accomplished was to wipe out the company entirely. We had to be hastily reconvened so that we could reinstate the company. I think the change that we had tried to make has never been made to this day, but at least the insurance company is back in business.
The present bill is good legislation. We have had the time to study it and to be satisfied that it is not doing anything more or less than it says it is doing. We join in supporting it and in helping it get through its three stages.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak during this third reading of the amendments to the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act.
A recurring theme in the recent deliberations over Canada's future is that we have to make some fundamental changes in the way we do business if our private sector is going to continue to compete successfully in an increasingly globalized marketplace.
To ensure their success in the years ahead, Canadian industries must learn to adapt much more quickly to rapid economic, political and technological changes. They must work to continually improve every facet of their businesses in order to compete with top competitors around the world.
In the agrifood industry this means using and developing new technologies and processes to increase crop yields; to develop a wider variety of processed food products; to ensure sustainable agricultural development and to ensure the highest possible level of food safety and quality. It also means that the industry must become more aggressive, innovative and self-reliant in marketing its products so that it can adjust to rapidly changing market conditions and move quickly to capitalize on new market opportunities.
The amendments before us will go a long way toward helping the agrifood industry become more successful competitors.
I want to clarify something at the outset. The Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act was originally passed to set up marketing agencies and has been used to create marketing boards in the feather and dairy industry. These amendments do not allow the establishment of marketing boards for their commodities. What we are talking about doing is changing the name of this bill to the National Farm Products Council in order to reflect its wider jurisdiction and to reflect the fact that the legislation touches more than just marketing agencies.
What is being proposed is to add a new section to the act. It will allow agrifood groups to charge levies called check-offs so that they can set up national promotional and research agencies for one or more farm products, agencies which will help and develop the products and processes they need to be more competitive on world markets.
These amendments to the Farm Marketing Agencies Act respond to numerous requests for change from a wide cross-section of the agrifood industry. The Canadian Cattlemen's Association, the Canadian Horticultural Council, the Canadian Pork Council, the Canadian Fruit Wholesalers Association, the Fresh for Flavour Foundation, Western Grains Research Foundation, the Canadian Honey Council, the Canadian Nursery Trade Association have all expressed an interest in national check-offs.
Indeed, these groups surveyed indicated that they would spend a portion of the funds on primary production research projects. We believe that the legislation will do a great deal to assist the industry in meeting the challenges of the future.
As well, the passage of this bill will send a clear signal to all Canadian industries that we are fully committed to making the regulatory changes needed to help them become more competitive. Competitiveness, of course, is a key element in the government's prosperity initiative. This is an excellent opportunity to put the words into action.
National check-off programs are also consistent with the new agrifood policies which are being developed by the government in consultation with the provinces, producers, consumer groups and other stakeholders in the agrifood industry.
May 1, 1992

Allowing the collection of mandatory or refundable levies to finance commodity based promotion and research agencies supports many of the goals articulated in the 1989 Growing Together paper. These include improved market responsiveness, shared responsibility for economic development between the public and private sectors and greater self-reliance to the agrifood industry.
Activities that could be supported by check-offs include market research, new product development, consumer education and advertising and promotion. Check-offs will encourage greater self-reliance because levies will be collected from the membership of the commodity group.
These proposed check-offs will not be imposed on agrifood groups. Indeed, no promotion and research agency will be set up unless a majority of the producers are in favour. Proposed amendments, therefore, place a strong emphasis on the wishes of individual producers.
In order to determine whether there is majority support, the Governor in Council may ask for a plebiscite. As well, the amendments provide for mandatory public hearings on the establishment of such agencies.
Furthermore, accountability to producers will also be ensured by producer membership on promotion and research agencies. Where there are no check-offs on imports, a majority of the agency members will be primary producers. These members can be appointed in any manner, including election by producers.
Finally, the National Farm Products Council will be responsible for ensuring that the promotion research agencies operate smoothly. If a problem is brought to its attention, the council will investigate and take necessary action.
This legislation will help level the playing field for Canadian producers. For example at present, Canadian cattle and beef producers pick up the whole tab for the beef information centre, but imported beef benefits from its promotional activities.
The objective of the check-offs is to fund research and promotion programs with two main goals: First, to
Government Orders
improve the competitive position of the product, and second, to expand domestic and foreign markets for the product.
In particular, it would support such activities as research into production, processing, distribution and marketing of the commodity. In short, check-offs would be used to enhance the competitiveness of the products. Until now, many of the industry's promotional programs have been ad hoc.
In addition, while Canadian products have a reputation for quality, Canada has lacked a national image in foods and has lagged behind in the development of value added. As a result, many producers and processors would prefer a more concerted and co-ordinated system whereby market promotion and development programs would be more aggressive and longer term.
Provincial check-offs have not been added within developing such a system. Therefore, producers have been looking for national check-offs to help establish such a system. Successful check-off programs could help the government achieve its target of 2.5 million new jobs by the year 2000.
Check-offs would permit commodity groups to develop market and promotion programs designed for the specific needs of their commodities. As well, they would give producers greater control over the establishment of research priorities and disbursement of research funds. This would give producers a greater interest in applying the results of the research.
We also recognize that in these days of intense multilateral trade negotiations, we must be sensitive to the possible requirements of new trade agreements. In this regard, I want to assure members of the House that our proposals do nothing to create an unfair trade advantage of the Canadian industry.
In the first place, the check-offs charged on imported products must equal those charged to domestic producers. We have no intention of breaking our international trade obligations. Second, where imports are involved, there will be representation from import organizations on the research and promotion agencies.

May 1, 1992
Business of the House
It is important as well to remember that beef, pork, potato and honey producers in the United States have check-off systems which apply to imported products.
The amendments we are proposing can provide our producers with access to the same kinds of check-off systems available to their U.S. counterparts.
As you know, Mr. Speaker, three amendments to Bill C-54 in committee were ruled inadmissible. The government then sought unanimous consent of the House to accept these amendments and received consent for two out of the three. The remaining amendment would allow wheat and barley produced in the Canadian Wheat Board designated area to be declared eligible for checkoff as part of the Promotion Research Agency.
This amendment was supported by organizations such as Prairie Pools, the Western Grains Research Foundation and the Canadian Wheat Board. Unfortunately the opposition would not accept this amendment despite industry's support. As a result, we must now wait for another opportunity to allow these farm products to be made eligible for check-offs.
Before concluding, I would like to address one myth that seems to have grown up around this piece of legislation and that is the belief that the federal government wants to get out of research and just let the farmers do it all. Far from it. Agriculture Canada is committed to research. Just last June the department backed a conference in Montreal called "Partnerships- A Focus on Technology" to get industry's views on where the research branch of the department should direct its resources.
As a result of that conference, the department will be concentrating on high-profile research the private sector is unable to undertake, newer work and value-added research. In addition, the Minister of Agriculture recently announced $170 million will be dedicated to funding projects under the green plan.
Agriculture Canada and the federal government remain committed to agricultural research. Bill C-54 will enable the industry to complement the research done by government with its own projects designed to meet its own priorities.
