The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. McKnight that Bill C-54, an act to amend the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act and other acts in consequence thereof be read the third time and passed.

Mr. Speaker, I am bit nervous about taking part in this debate today because I am very familiar with the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act. In fact, I was one of the charter members for the National Farm Products Marketing Council in 1972.
I was nominated by the Ontario Federation of Agriculture. It was a great honour for me to be involved in setting up the first three national agencies. The third one did not come into being until after I had left the council. When I was first appointed I understood it was only going to be a part-time position but before I ever started I found out it was a full-time position.
It was a tremendous experience as a Canadian to be involved in the negotiations with the various provinces, the various producer groups, across Canada which was really Confederation working at its very best.
The producers had asked for this legislation. It is only in a country like Canada where they would have come up with the necessary transfers of authority in federal-provincial agreements to made the system work very, very effectively. Very quickly it became the most sophisticated marketing system in the world. It has never contributed to surpluses that are of concern to us around the world, surpluses that are being attacked at the present time through the GATT.
Government Orders
We gained a part of that success through article XI of the GATT whereby the restrictions imposed on our own producers would be imposed on imports and therefore we could plan ahead to supply our domestic market and any export markets that might come along.
As these systems were refined they very quickly brought stability to the poultry farmers across Canada; a stability that is only equalled by those of the dairy farmers across Canada who had their own legislation that was brought in in earlier years.
If the purpose of this change is to enable the producers of Canada to adapt more quickly, and with better processing adapt to sustainable agriculture, then of course I have no problems. It is interesting that only the poultry and dairy sectors have the returns at the present time to adapt to sustainable agriculture. If we look at the problems gathering around this planet we have to be very, very concerned about the future food supply for generations to come.
This bill allows the Farm Products Marketing Council to provide the authority to the producers to collect levies; levies that can be collected if the majority of producers agree. Other producers are not already covered by this legislation but I should point out, as I understand the amendments of the act, this could also be used to collect moneys on imported products that are being sold in Canada and in effect be used to promote imported products.
When I look at this it is a grave concern because in March 1989 I asked the Minister of Agriculture what he was going to do about the million pounds a week of no-roll beef coming into Canada. Of course the response was it must be needed or it would not be coming in.
Two years later I asked again and the response was very similar. Just recently there was a regulation change that was supposed to deal with the situation. It is a regulatory amendment and requires that a beef carcass or a portion thereof, including a sub-primal cut, not be imported or shipped from a registered establishment unless the beef is packed in a bulk container and that container is marked with grade, name of the product, or in the case of ungraded beef, with the words "ungraded beef".

May 1, 1992
Government Orders
No-rolled beef is ungraded beef. When you grade a carcass of beef you run a roller down the side that stamps on the grade and in the case of Canadian grades it is grades Al, 2, 3, or 4 and then of course Cl, 2, 3, or 4 as cow beef. We had some changes just recently that include the triple A. The point is that the ungraded beef that is coming into Canada, even though a lot of it is boxed and wrapped, could very well be cow beef.
Here is the hooker on this new regulation which makes it meaningless. Even though the container or bulk container has to be marked with the name and the grade which is the Canadian grade equivalent coming into Canada, there is no legal requirement for the retailer to display that grade or the standard.
Here we are making it legal to collect levies that include levies on imported products coming into Canada in direct competition with our products here in Canada and at the retail level there is no requirement whatsoever to show what the grade is, to show the Canadian consumer what they are buying and consequently it will be working to the detriment of our own industry.
I maintain that any imported food has to be raised and processed or produced and processed, whichever we want to use, whether it is vegetables, crops, or meats, and processed under similar standards as that produced in Canada. On many occasions I have said in this House that we may have products that are not allowed to be used in Canada such as chemicals, pesticides, herbicides, or hormones, but imported foods can have a minimum level of those substances involved. It is not allowed to be used in Canada, we have a zero tolerance level in this country, but it does not apply to imported foods because of minimum standards.
I want to go even further. Just last night on Prime Time Live ABC television there was a program on meat contamination in the U.S. I am just going to touch on it very briefly. The United States Department of Agriculture has a Streamlined Inspection System, really giving the processing plants the powers to inspect their own meat, the honour system, and 20 per cent of U.S. beef falls under this system.
I was shocked at what we saw on that program and the conditions. I cannot comment on the authenticity of that
program, however they did have a letter advising a plant that an inspector would be coming on a certain date, giving approximately five days warning so the plant could clean up its operation before the inspector arrived.
They had 10 samples of meat tested by the U.S.A. Department of Agriculture and seven of the ten proved to be contaminated.
I am also deeply concerned about what is happening in the poultry industry. The Canadian poultry industry is one of the most sophisticated in the world. It shows a profit to primary producers under legislation provided for in the act we are debating today. I am also deeply concerned that the agencies established under this act are under open attack, an attack that started here. It is an attack against the subsidies being paid to Canadian farmers a year ago last October, an attack that started on the front bench on the government side when the minister stated that. There is $8 billion worth of subsidies given to Canadian agriculture, $2 billion of which goes to dairy farmers. In actual fact, there is only $267 million of subsidy going to the industrial milk producers in Canada.
We had a whole series of editorials and articles in the various media and even more recently, attacks by other people in the food sector against our marketing systems here in Canada.
On March 25 a representative of the Grocery Manufacturers Association made the statement that supply management costs consumers in excess of $5 billion a year in Canada. How could that possibly be? The total farm gate value of dairy and poultry products, the value the farmers receive for those products in Canada, only amounts to $4.8 billion. Are our Canadian farmers supposed to produce for nothing and then subsidize to have it taken away? Is this what they are suggesting? I suggest not. Farmers have a right to a standard of living similar to that of the rest of Canada. They have a right to an income that is commensurate with that of the rest of Canada and yet we are being attacked.
I want to say at this point that the Canadian consumer spends the second lowest in terms of disposable income on food purchases of any country in the world. Only the United States is slightly lower, a little over 1 per cent lower. If you look at food costs in capital cities of the world, Canada is the lowest. Right here in Ottawa food
May 1, 1992

costs are lower than they are in Washington, the capital of the United States.
What is all the fuss about? We even had one person claim to represent 2,000 independent grocery retailers. This person called himself the head of the Ontario Food Alliance. Incidentally, I should point out that this Ontario Food Alliance is a subsidiary of a very large distribution and retailing conglomerate here in Canada.
He questioned some of the statistics used when I showed the spreads between the producer price and the processor price. Spreads at that level are very consistent. The retail price went up dramatically over the last 10 years. He could not disagree with my figures because they were accurate. They are figures from the Agriculture Canada food basket commentary or Statistics Canada and they included specials. Specials appear from time to time in the various retail outlets.
He said it was misleading because when the farmer sells chickens, the head and the feathers have to be taken off and the body eviscerated before it is sold. The fact is we quoted eviscerated weight to the producer.
I should point out that within a day or two after the farmers protested here on Parliament Hill on February 21, the vice-president of a very large fast-food chicken outlet said on national television here in Canada that the reason chicken prices were too high here in Canada is because the farmer charges too much.
Let me say that one of those chickens is sold to the processor for $2 for the entire chicken. It does not matter if it is dead or alive, he got $2 for it. I never heard of a farmer delivering a load of dead chickens to a processor in my life. I never, ever got paid for a dead chicken. However, the processor got $1.50 for processing that chicken and cutting it into nine pieces and those nine pieces sold for $11.50 including the GST. That is a box of chicken, nine pieces.
The handling charges get GST.

The retail price was $10 plus GST.
If the farmer gave that company the chicken for nothing and if the processor processed it for nothing, the total cost of those two things is $3.50, then of course the price would be roughly $8 for the retailer. That price is $2 higher than what a similar box was being sold for in
Government Orders
the United States. That includes the cost of the chicken, the processing and the margin of the retailer. Yet he accused the farmers of charging too much.
I just want to go on a little further in that regard. That same individual from the Ontario Food Alliance stated that only 10 to 15 cents worth of wheat was required to grow a chicken. That is nonsense.
First, Ontario chickens are not fed wheat but a mixture of corn, other grains and protein supplements. In the cost of production formula that is used by the Ontario Chicken Marketing Agency and audited by Peat Marwick they determine the cost of feed for a kilogram of live chicken to be 47.27 cents or, if that chicken is grown for specialty markets as I am speaking of here, the cost of feed is 83.6 cents for that total chicken.
This individual only underestimated the cost of feed by 557 per cent! Talk about an error. In addition to the cost of feed, the cost of the baby chick to the farmer is 49 cents. If the farmer received $2 for the bird when it was completely ready for market, he would have a return of 14 cents a bird to cover his investment, labour, management and risk.
When people say they want cheaper chicken, I want to give an example of cheaper chicken. We have standards and management practices in Canada where after every flock of chickens goes through a bam, the bam is cleaned and in many cases disinfected. Our processors are under strict government inspection. We have the highest quality inspection system of any in the world.
I have an article about some work that has been going on in the United States at the present time. This one is from the May 26, 1991 edition of the Atlanta Journal Constitution, headed "The poultry industry's hidden perils". It states:
Millions of tainted birds make it to market, inspectors say.
I let some of my colleagues in on the gory details the other day, but I do not think I want them on the record here. It also states:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture, responsible for ensuring that poultry products are wholesome, is failing so completely that the distinctive USDA seal of approval today no longer guarantees that chicken is safe to eat, said more than six dozen USDA inspectors at the nation's largest poultry plants.

May 1, 1992
Government Orders
Even more recently is an article dated March 7,1992, a year later. It states:
USDA scientists have found as many as eight out of ten chickens tested are contaminated with salmonella, and as many as nine out of ten chickens tested are contaminated with (other bacteria). Millions of people become ill every year after eating contaminated meat, several thousand die.
If we want cheaper chicken, is this how we want it, or do we want the systems we have in Canada? I suggest that this legislation and the amendments before us today have another purpose to them. The pricing authority under the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act that allows the producers of Canada to price their products based on a cost of production formula is on the way out.
I would be very surprised if the national marketing agencies are not being stripped of their powers and will soon lose these price setting authorities due to the direction of this government. I would also be very surprised if the National Farm Products Marketing Council has not already received its marching orders in relation to the cost of production formulas used to establish prices for the efficient producer, prices that provide a return for management, labour, investment and the efficient producer. I expect these agencies will have to have abandon these prices in the very near future. They are under pressure to do so.
Let us look at what is happening in that system which the various pressure groups are pushing hard to do away with, claiming that prices are too high. First let me just say what happened south of us. In the United States the government spent $757 million to buy surplus dairy products, along with price supports that cost the average U.S. householder $100 per year.
As I said earlier, only our industrial milk receives a subsidy. Poultry does not receive one red cent and it has not since agencies came into being.
In 1983 the U.S. government paid its farmers $2.5 billion to remove dairy cows from the industry. That was a supreme sacrifice on the part of cows. They had to pass under the golden arches and come out as hamburgers. To placate the worries of ranchers who were competing for that same meat market, Congress has to authorize another $400 million to buy up the surplus beef that resulted.
It also subsidizes exporters that sell milk abroad. These exporters buy milk on the open market and sell
the product for less than they paid. However they are subsidized to make up the difference, plus a small mark-up. That government spent $46.6 million on this.
If we look at the stability and the economic foundation of that industry, they simply do not exist. A report of the U.S. general accounting office shows that between August 1990 and May 1991 prices paid to farmers in the U.S. for milk dropped by 21.5 per cent. However, milk prices in supermarkets fell by just 4.6 per cent and the price of cheese and other products only dropped by 1 per cent.
Who skimmed off the profits? In the U.S. dairy industry there is absolute chaos with thousands of producers being forced out of business every month. I read in a weekly American farm newspaper this week that they expect the prices to drop even further. Had they instead passed on those prices to the consumers, one university study pointed out that cheese prices would have dropped as much as 48 cents a pound at the retail level.
These findings are very similar to my study Compare the Shared Phase One that I published last August. Wheat prices in Canada dropped by 43 per cent to the producer between 1980 and 1990. Yet the price of whole wheat cereals increased by 192.4 per cent and soda biscuits by 235 per cent.
We have the best marketing systems of any country in the world. Why should we revert to something that is so utterly ridiculous as what is being proposed in the direction we are being pushed by some of the very large business interests in this country?
When I look at the returns to the agriculture producers in Canada, the five-year rate of return on assets including all government payments to the Canadian farmers but excluding farmer-owner labour, those returns were 6.2 per cent.
By contrast, Canada's food manufacturers have an average five-year rate of return of 16.9 per cent. One manufacturer had a five-year average return of 69 per cent and a one-year return of 192.7 per cent.
If this industry is to stay healthy in Canada all sectors have to have a return on investment, management, labour and risk. Five major food distributors in Canada had an average five-year rate of return of 17.1 per cent.
May 1, 1992

In the dairy industry, the return to producers is approximately 9 per cent, and in the poultry industry it may be slightly higher, between 9 and 10 per cent. Why all the fuss by the big corporations and the Consumer Association of Canada against our marketing systems?
Why are they not pointing their finger at others who are making far more in the rate of return than our producers? By comparison, the Canadian banks had a five-year average rate of return of 13.3 per cent.
Our food distribution system is doing very well. It ranks right up there, according to the The Globe and Mail's Report on Business, in the top 1,000. I am not taking a shot at the retailers at all. I want to put this on record.
The normal food retail store does not make a big return on the dollar volume of business because normally it is only perhaps 1.5 cents or 2 cents and sometimes it is 3 or 4 cents. It does not make a big return on that but you have to realize it turns its inventory over 27 times a year. In the food distribution sector, it is abut 18 times a year.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext: It is having trouble, old fellow.

It is not really having trouble, because the biggest retailer chain in Canada last year, if you look at its annual report, had its best year in quite some time.
One chain in western Canada, operating only from Thunder Bay west, sent $538.7 million in dividends back to the parent company in the U.S. and it borrowed $474 million to do that. It is in its annual report, and guess who is going to pay the interest and pay back the principal? It is going to be the consumers of Canada who pay that back, and yet they want cheaper prices.
I indicated earlier that the average retailer is not making a huge return on his dollar volume. I want to make that very clear, but the product is turned over on an average of 27 times a year.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext: Just defending small business.
Good enough.
As you should with vigour.

The interesting part is that we are told that we have to become more competitive.
Government Orders
In the food distribution sector, the level of profits is slightly over 7 per cent more than with a comparable industry in the United States. I should point out that the average Canadian food distributor had 190 per cent more profit on sales than the average Canadian retailer in 1989 and 1990.
Canada put together the systems, beginning with the Canadian Wheat Board in the 1930s, I think it was 1935. It was, incidentally, brought in by the Conservative government of the day.
It was brought in to protect the producers of this country against the concentration of power in the marketplace at the time. Those powers are now being slowly but surely eroded by this administration.
I want to comment on a news article in which my colleague from Winnipeg-St. James was quoted recently. He pointed out that the flow of grain that is going to start from Canada to the United States markets is going to increase. It is a flow of grain that does not come under the Canadian Wheat Board system due to this government's action.
I should point out that recently I compared the returns for a 10-year period of the Canadian wheat producers in western Canada to those of the U.S. sales on-board ship in the Mississippi or the Texas gulf coast. Eight years out of ten, our Canadian producers return was substantially higher than the level of price received for that product.
This shows the value of this system to our Canadian producers, who produce the highest quality product of anyone in the world. They are obviously recognized around the world for the quality and their ability to supply the markets.
Slowly but surely that system is being eroded by the actions of this government. Consequently, this is the basis of my fears.
Something is very wrong in our system. Something is very wrong when this government starts taking away these systems. It has completely ignored the fact that five top companies in Canada account for 69 per cent of food distribution.
I am very concerned that we look at this very seriously. I am very concerned that the fanners of Canada are being sacrificed by taking away some of the powers they have now. They are being sacrificed by being told they have to compete in world markets and compete with world prices for our own domestic markets when their

May 1, 1992
Government Orders
input costs are about 25 per cent higher than those in the country to the south of us.
There has to be a level playing field and it has to include input costs, food standards and quality standards. It has to reflect the need for an adequate supply of high quality Canadian food for our consumers at reasonable prices.
I submit here today that our Canadian fanners, through the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act and our other piece of legislation, have met that challenge. They supply our Canadian consumers with large quantities of wholesome, good food at very reasonable prices. We have to maintain those systems and ensure their continuation. We cannot allow them to be chipped away and have their powers eroded.

Mr. Speaker, under the rules of the House my speech must be confined to something under 20 minutes and I will fit into that range.
I was very interested in what the speaker before me said when he took a very broad range approach at third reading of this bill and spent some time dealing with his concerns that the whole concept of national marketing boards is at risk with this government.
I believe that is probably the case, but in the 20 minutes I have, I wish to confine my remarks to the actual changes the government has proposed to that marketing legislation and point out what it has done. I believe it has probably set the stage for a very easy move to what it has been describing in its rhetoric as a new age of marketing boards, a new style of marketing agency. All it will have to do is cut part II out of the act as it now stands after today.
Part 1 of the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act establishes a National Marketing Council, which my friend from Lambton-Middlesex served on and which he mentioned at the beginning of his remarks. This is the council that is made up of producers and consumers and sometimes other individuals appointed by the government to overview the marketing and the business being conducted by agencies which might be set up as national agencies under part II of the act. It is under part II that the supply managed agencies have been established since 1972. The agency is for eggs, chicken, turkey, hatching eggs, et cetera.
The amendments we have been dealing with in Bill C-54 are amendments which establish a new part II.
These part III agencies will not have the depth and the scope of the part II agencies. They will simply be established for the collection of levies for promotion and research.
Under the Constitution, a lot of members of the House who are here today realize that agriculture is one of the shared jurisdictions. As long as the agricultural product is inside of a provincial boundary it is guided by and is a provincial responsibility. Therefore, production in this country is basically seen to be a provincial responsibility.
However, once that product has to move in trade or commerce across provincial boundaries, it becomes a federal responsibility. Therefore, the federal government has tended to take charge of trade and commerce aspects of agriculture, of the kind of regulation that is required to make trade simpler and to get it into other countries because the federal government is also responsible for international trade.
What is being proposed with this new part III would be to set in progress a system that would permit producers to establish a marketing or check-off levy to be used for promotion and market research of a commodity under this new part III. They will then be able to go to the federal jurisdiction and ask for the power for those levies to be taken on the same product that is imported into Canada.
We have heard from beef producers and some of the horticultural producers. They might be interested in utilizing part III as a means of collecting levies whereby they could use the levies to promote their products in Canada and outside Canada as a means of expanding the market.
There were some problems that emerged when we began to investigate how this process might work. I would like to spend a few moments going through what I see as being some of the problems with this particular approach.
I have a bias and I will begin by stating that. The best and most efficient way for agriculture products to be marketed and promoted is through the kind of marketing boards that are possible under part II of the existing legislation. I speak as having had some experience in
May 1, 1992

this. When you go into another country to try to push pork sales, which was the case in my experience, or beef or any other commodity, it is much easier to promote that product when you are dealing with the potential buyers if you can sign a contract with them after you have convinced them of the great things that Canadian pork can do for them as Japanese businessmen, consumers or Japanese wholesaler-retailers. If you are able to sign a contract for the particular kind of cuts you have interested them in, then that is effective promotion and marketing. It is an effective way of promoting a product.
If you go over to the Japanese, in this case promoting beef which is not marketed under a marketing board in Canada, and convince them of the joys of eating, marketing and selling Canadian beef, and you have them all convinced and they are all enthusiastic about having some Canadian beef to market, they will ask how they can get this. You will say you will arrange a further trade mission to come over and maybe discuss that very thing and maybe you can get some of the processors interested in coming to talk to them.
Their enthusiasm wanes and the delay between when the processors may or may not arrive causes the whole effect of your promotion to have been considerably downgraded.
As well, there is a problem when taking this commodity-by-commodity approach and concentrating only on the promotion of the counter-promotions that are going to occur from similar commodities. When beef increases its promotion funds, what do you expect pork producers to do? What do you expect chicken producers to do? They too are going to retaliate by adding to the amount of promotion funds collected from producers.
In the end what you have is a system that does a very good job of collecting a lot of extra levies from producers. That is all to the credit and the good of advertising agencies which engage in promotion, but it does not put any more money in the pockets of the producers as a result. So there are some problems with the concept.
When we looked deliberately at the legislation, we noticed that new part III does not mention anything about the spending of the funds and accountability that the producer group so established has to comply with. There is nothing that says what proportion of the product
Government Orders
the levy can be against. It does not say whether it can only be on 1 per cent of farm sales or whether it can be as high as 100 per cent. The legislation is absolutely silent on that matter.
When I attempted to introduce amendments to the legislation through Parliament a few days ago, government members sat silent. When the vote came they shouted the proposal down when I proposed that the size of levies should not exceed one-half of 1 per cent of the farm-gate price. They wanted to leave it wide open. They did not explain why they wanted to leave it wide open. They were silent as to why. They simply thought it was not a good idea for Parliament to put limits on this and future ministers as to how big those levies can be.
The legislation is a little sloppy with regard to implementation. It says only that the minister or the marketing council have to be, and the word used in the legislation is "satisfied" that such an agency needs to exist.
Essentially, it is possible for a minister and his council, after all he appoints the council, to establish an agency almost at will. There is no real requirement for hearings, unless the marketing council decides to challenge the minister on it. If the marketing council and the minister are simply satisfied that such a promotion agency should exist, it will exist.
On the other side, there is no way in the legislation for producers to bring to an end such a promotion agency. I attempted to put in such amendments to the bill stating that where 5 per cent of the contributing producers petition the council, a hearing would be held to decide whether the agency would be continued, but that was shouted down by the government side as well when the vote came.
These agencies that may be established for collecting levies for promotion and so on also can collect from importers. I thought that it only made some sense if importers were consulted as well and were involved in the process. The legislation is not terribly clear on what role or how much consultation would be involved for importers either.
As I have already said, the legislation does not limit the size of the levy. We presume it could be up to 100 per cent. We suppose that the councils and the minister

would realize that that was far beyond the call of common sense, but government members refuse to allow Parliament to put a limit on this minister or any future ministers in that regard.
Another thing I am concerned about in this legislation is that it does not provide any requirement as to how the funds collected under these levies will be spent. I have spent some time reviewing a number of provincial agencies that have been established in the various provinces to do this so-called promotion.
Some of the agencies are extremely inefficient in converting a farmer's money into promotion and research funds. A great many of them put less than 50 per cent of the funds that they collect for the purposes of promotion and research actually into promotion and research. In other words, over half of the moneys collected are spent in the agency's own administrative costs. Often times these agencies have been struck in some of the provinces for the purposes of establishing an organization and a financial basis for a relatively small group of people claiming to be a commodity group. I submit that does not serve Canadian farmers very well.
I thought it only made sense for Parliament to levy some requirements through this act that the bulk of the funds, and I had suggested for discussion purposes at least 80 per cent of the funds, collected should in fact go for promotion and research. Again, the government members shouted that down and said that no, they did not really have to. We can accept by their thinking that virtually none of the moneys collected for that purpose actually have to go to that purpose. The agency seems to be responsible for that. The act remains silent as to what one would think was normal logic that the bulk of the funds should go for promotion and research since that is what they were collected for.
The act was also silent, although some of the government spokespeople mentioned their continued responsibility for research and trade promotion, on a firm legislative commitment that the federal government is still going to carry on the same proportion of responsibility as has been the case in the past.
That is important because the federal government's support and financial commitment to research and to trade promotion has not been keeping up with inflation and the proportion of trade that we have in the world. They have been backing off from their responsibility.
Some of us fear that new part III in this legislation will be used as a crutch on the part of this government to encourage farmers to go out and collect their own money if they have a particular research project or particular type of promotion they want to do. The government will simply use part III to get away from their longstanding commitments in this area and simply tell the farmers: "Look, you have the power under part III of this national Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act to go out and collect the funding for that and to fund it yourself. We wash our hands of responsibility for this".
Because of all of the shortcomings in the legislation, I think it will be of dubious utility to the farming community. Its effectiveness and efficiency are not going to be great for the reasons I have outlined because of the cross-commodity competition that it will engender and the ineffectual means that the commodity groups will be limited to in terms of pushing new products and pushing into new markets.
Even though the government says that this bill is attempting to enhance competitiveness, it has missed a great opportunity to encourage producers in this country to use part II of the old legislation which would have made Canada's producers more competitive. It would have given producers of more commodities a chance to expand into new markets in a meaningful way that would have provided a true system of integrated market penetration where the promotion, the research and the product all follow together because they are under one roof and on one desk through a national marketing agency.
The producer check-offs that are used now are certainly less than efficient. A great many of them spend less. They spend barely half of the funds collected. Some of them spend less than half of the funds they collected on the purposes for which they were collected, namely promotion and research.

I do not expect great things from this. I do hope, however, that the suspicions of my hon. friend who spoke before me from Lambton-Middlesex are not borne out, that in fact the government does not have in the back of its mind as part of its long-term plan to do away with existing national marketing agencies.
Part II continues to be a vital part of the marketing system in the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act. The government will begin to encourage producers of other products to use that part of the act to set up national agencies, not just for supply management purposes but as single desk selling agencies and function like the Canadian Wheat Board for the international sales of wheat and barley. This kind of an agency could be set up for a more directed marketing approach for pork, potatoes or apples. This is the way for Canadians to penetrate world markets. It is the most logical approach.
I only regret that the government did not choose to put its efforts into making part II agencies work better instead of creating a side show with these part III agencies which I contend will be expensive, inefficient and quite ineffectual.

Madam Speaker, I listened with very great interest to our colleague here in the House, the hon. member for Lambton-Middlesex, who has been a farmer for many years and who obviously knows what he is talking about concerning the importance of our agricultural system in Canada.
Since my colleague described the present situation in the United States with respect to grading and the inspection system, we are inclined to think that we here in Canada are far ahead of our southern neighbours when it comes to inspection and ensuring that all products on the market are in perfect condition and safe for the consumer.
My colleague from Lambton-Middlesex indeed showed that this bill in particular goes a little farther than was believed, in that the supply management system that we have here in Canada has served our farmers well. As my colleague showed, poultry producers are assured of reasonable prices that meet their production costs, but we see that their profit margin is very small.
Where is the problem, he asks, and so do I? We guarantee a product that meets all the inspection requirements and our standards are among the highest if
Government Orders
not the highest in the world. Products in Canada are sold at a very reasonable price when you consider that retail prices are merely 1 per cent higher here than in the United States. As the hon. member said, we have in Ottawa the best prices that can be found in any capital in the world.
The question is then, as my hon. colleague asked, where is the problem? Indeed, what major national, transnational and multinational companies have in mind is to maximize profits. And so they will, but at what price? Would we be prepared to compromise Canada's good name by selling substandard products, whether it be eggs, poultry or beef for that matter?
In southern states, according to a U.S. T.V. broadcast, the market is severely flawed. My colleague from Lambton-Middlesex has clearly showed, with positive proof, that we have an extraordinary advantage here in Canada, in that our prices are among the best in the world.
We should therefore look out and it is the role of the members of this House to look after the best interest of all Canadians. We cannot count on big companies or multinationals to satisfy perfect health requirements. We saw in the United States the big corporations leave that aside. The inquiries that were made revealed serious flaws.
In Canada, it is obvious that we cannot have that. However, if we let the situation deteriorate to the point where the biggest stakeholders would literally dictate to the government the conditions for "productive" production, if we want to be competitive, there is a limit. I do not think anybody is opposed to ensuring that the inspection is conducted and that no detail is overlooked to ensure compliance with all the sanitary requirements as regards agricultural production as a whole in Canada.
As my colleague demonstrated, this bill as a whole presents a risk and we must be aware of that. It is obvious that Canadian farmers are not among the richest people in the country. Given the number of hours they work, those farmers are entitled to a reasonable profit. The figures all show-and they are not from me nor from my colleague, but from Statistics Canada-that our farmers make a profit that is below average if you look at all the businesses in the country.
Our role here, and especially the role of the government, which is responsible for the administration of the country, is to guarantee to the population that our production cannot in any way, be contaminated, that we can be assured that all products meet those requirements that are so important for the population.

In concluding, I hope, as my colleague mentioned, that we will be vigilant concerning this issue and that we will ensure that all farm products meet those requirements. You can meet those requirements when you are guaranteed a certain price. The inspection that will then be carried will ensure sound management to the Canadian consumers.
